Excellent breakfast restaurant!  This is our "go to" place for brunch in the west loop.  The french toast, eggs, fruit bowl, and mimosas are to die for!!

Wishbone used to be my brunch spot before my eyes were opened to the wonders of Yelp.  It has pretty good food, especially the Crawfish Cake Benedicts, but honestly, in hindsight, every second I waited in line to eat here was a complete waste of time. When you consider the sheer number of places in Chicago where you can get brunch with zero wait and then consider the quality of the places where you will have to wait, there is absolutely no point in waiting to eat here. I had probably eaten about 12 brunches here before I hit it up for dinner.  There was zero wait and the actual food experience was similar.  That is to say it was pretty good and at a price that closely mirrors its quality.  It's a good option for a group dinner if some in your party are more budget conscious and/or not particularly adventurous. But seriously, why is there a poodle on the t-shirts?  What does that have to do with a Wishbone?

What more can I ask for? Quick friendly service, delicious meal (shrimp and cheesy grits-w/ brussels sprouts as a side. The bite size cornbread was decent but the dinner roll was dry. The place was warmly lit, spacey and at the same time cozy.  My waiter was very attentive and I felt very well treated. I highly recommend this spot based on the service and cheesy grits :) I really want to try the crunchy french toast, I shall try to return =) Updated:  I ordered the Asheville Salad...delicious. I also finally ordered the crunchy french toast...it's a huge portion so I'm glad I split it and treated it as a dessert. It was so delicious!! I love this place. =)

I went here with a big group for a birthday dinner.  The restaurant was able to accommodate a reservation for 18 people, and the service was fantastic.  Our waiter deserved a medal. Wishbone is great for drinks.  Our birthday party got a great start from the $5 hurricanes (good taste, good strength), $6 whiskey sours (mmm), and $12 bourbon flights (generous pours of Basil Haydens, Makers 47). The food was tasty, but not remarkable.  It is coastal Southern, so a mix of Carolinas and Louisana dishes.  I has the crawfish cakes with lemon butter sauce, a side of macaroni, and collard greens.  It was filling for a good price.  Next time, I would like to the shrimp and grits, and I hear the brunch is tasty.  Wishbone is vegetarian friendly, and has several tasty looking menu options for veggies.

Wishbone use to carter for an org that I worked and the always did a great job. I have been here a couple of times for breakfast and while I was not wow'd it was a decent. meal. The lunch leaves something to be desired. Dishes you would think would be packed with flavor were mediocre.  The saute spinach was yummy but the mash potatoes seems to come from a box. Our server seemed to disappear and while she was nice did not make the effort to make sure we had what we needed. Not sure if I will be in a rush to go back.

The food was decent, but I bet sub par on busy days.The waitstaff is very nice, but I didn't eat anything that was remarkable. I'm sure you could find an average diner and have an equally blasé meal devoid of the hokey, almost Cracker Barrel feel of the external dining space. I guess it's a great place if you live close by and are hungry,  you are hungover or you are hungry/hungover nearby in the chilly Winter months.

Try the Green Smoothie! I love this food!  And the wait staff!  The flavors are great. Some of my favorite things: Try the hot organic 7 grain cereal that comes with brown sugar, raisins, and your choice of milk (or soy)!  It's delicious! Wishbone now has Kalibur NA beer!  Hooray!  My favorite!  Thank you, Reyna! Vegetarian plate-you choose 3 sides! Oatmeal, fresh fruit & coffee - good coffee - what a wonderful start to a the day!   Lentil soup Blackened catfish po'boy sandwich -yummy in tummy How about veggie burger-brown rice, oats, lentils, black beans on black bread with lettuce, tomato, raw onion & Swiss The decor is fun and casual. I highly recommend Wishbone on Washington! No white tablecloths, just good food with good pricing and good service. Street parking or valet. Clean restrooms.

4/5 stars for both service and food.  Saw little variation from what's on offer at the other location, so all of this applies to both: -Sauteed trout special: delicious.  Just the right amount of butter, perfectly breaded, carefully seasoned. -Pulled pork: above average for Chicago.  The choice of sauces is a nice touch. -Vegetarian hoe cakes: fantastic.  Light and fluffy with a generous assortment of veggies all cooked just right. -Always an impressive beer and cocktail selection, seems like they rotate some items out seasonally. -Love the corn muffins and the sides (have tried almost all of them, all very tasty). -Friendly, attentive, unfussy service; vibrant, fun atmosphere.

This is a solid three stars.  I've been here more times than I can count and it's always delicious.  Their breakfasts are certainly the best reason to show up.  Even though they are often packed on the weekends, it's worth the wait.  They have a good selection of southern inspired options such as biscuits and gravy and grits.  Their home fries are a great supplement to any meal.   Service is spotty.  Sometimes you're able to get great service and you get in and out in a relatively quick amount of time.  At other times, it takes forever.  There is no telling when or what section this will happen in so it's all about the luck of the draw.  Also, though the food is always good, the quality can vary one visit to the other.
Shrimp and Grits. Possibly best on the planet. Get it with the mac and cheese or sauteed spinach.

Such a West Loop favorite.... For reasons unknown. The place is aways packed but i have no idea why. Okay, so their biscuits are pretty good and they cook their grits as they should be. But other than that the food is under par. I have really tried to find my "Go-to" dish but I yet to find one. The omelets are less than fluffy, fried eggs undercooked, crab cakes... Mushy served w a teaspoon of hollandaise sauce, and dishes are just plain.  I continue to be disappointed but yes I still go. Why.... Convenience. It is a block away and there is usually min to no wait. From now on I go for my last resort, pancakes. Can u mess up pancakes?

One of the very few creole/Southern places in the city. I always come here for brunch and have thoroughly enjoyed the entrees I've had. Everyone I've taken here always seem to enjoy themselves as well. I've tried various egg dishes and more Southern dishes such as shrimp and grits and it has all been quite delicious. One of my other favorite items is their Electric Lemonade - a great brunch drink option if you are looking for something other than Bloody Mary.
Been hearing about this place for awhile now.  Decided to finally try it out.  I really enjoyed it.  The food was great.  Loved the atmosphere.  Need to try this place.

Pretty good chow. The beet juice was awesome. I had the blackened catfish po-boy and it was good but remulade sauce was missing and sandwich itself was kinda small. That did help me keep my calorie count down.

I only ordered delivery, but oh em gee! I think I have found another Vegan-friendly place that my meat-eater friends would like too. They actually label what's vegan on their menu!  Although I am a yank, I did live in Memphis for two years. Wishbone nails the southern food as far as I am concerned. The black bean cakes are basically giant black bean fritters. The collards are boiled and a bit salty, just how I like them. The salsa gave the black bean cakes a little kick. But actually, what I was most excited about was their coleslaw. I never cared for creamy coleslaw, but I loved the more oily, vinegary slaw I had in Memphis. That's what Wishbone serves! I inhaled that first before touching the black bean cakes, which had turned a little soggy due to greens' juice spilling over (darn delivery).  I had enough food for two meals, but was pretty hungry that night. I ate most of it... I will definitely try them again, and they are now my yummiest delivery option.
Best shrimp w/grits I have ever tasted and the Garlic salad is the bomb! Jambaliya omlet is sooooo good.

Everything I ordered was delicious here and we all cleared our plates.  I had the standard breakfast of 2 eggs scrambled with sausage and hash browns and cornbread.  It was all well cooked, fresh and fast.  The service was great, and fortunately, we didn't have to wait.  It's not cheap, but it's well done and worth every penny.

My mother introduced me to Wishbone years ago, back when she still lived in Chicago! This is such a Chicago staple. A great place after your Saturday hair appointment.  I always get the same thing. I've been here hundreds of times but I never deviate, its shameful: The Louisiana Chicken Salad with spinach. It always treats me right. I promise the next five times I will try something different.
The food was decent, but triple check your bill before you pay. They like to "accidentally" add things you never ordered onto the bill.

For a visit at 9 a.m. Saturday, November 24. So I set out to visit Le Peep.  I hadn't been in a while and was craving their crab cakes.  To my dismay, they are no longer in the West Loop so my bro and I went across the street to Wishbone.  I'm familiar with the location on Lincoln Ave in Lakeview so I kinda had an idea about the menu.   It was very early Saturday so we were offered to sit wherever we'd like.  I appreciated that.  The disappointing part was staff.  I could hear the staff yelping (ha!) from in the kitchen and behind the counter.  I could barely converse with my brother.  Then we saw someone wearing pink, baby phat jogging pants and could see hear panty-line.  Not what's up.  She and her colleague sat around the wall from us, but they were so loud we could hear them.  So my brother and I are fighting to talk over staff behind the counter, staff seated near us and the general conversation of others.  I mean, it was ridiculous.   That said, if I could take the shrimp and grits and put them in a separate atmosphere, I'd love this place!  Shrimp and Grits were absolutely delicious.  I'll try again, but if it's the same I won't be back and will probably do the Shrimp and Grits as take out every now and then.

After trying to find a new breakfast spot after driving around in the west loop, we stumbled into Wishbone. Luckily at 12pm we barely had to wait. I was excited to try it out and eat some southern inspired brunch.  The place is huge & busy, so I let our waiter slide with somethings, like giving me Ice water when I said no Ice, or you know forgetting my drink or you know not giving us silverware until 10 minutes after we had our food. Actually it wasn't even him who finally got it for us even though we asked him 2 times. I flagged down a busgirl in the kitchen who took for ever but did finally give us silverware.  So when we finally ate food was a bit cold, I had the shrimp & grits. It was good & surprisingly a ton of shrimp but it would of been better if it hadn't been sitting. Graham D. had the french toast & he was pretty meh. about it.  If the service wasn't so shotty it'd prolly be 3* and I'm not really one to gripe on service but this guy was pretty pretty bad.

I frequent this place regularly because it is across from my work. They are consistent, the staff is awesome and the food is pretty good. I appreciate that they have a ton of veggie options, juices, good coffee, and something for everyone.  It is great for groups, business, family, and pretty much anyone/everyone. It is very cozy, and has a lot of good energy.

I debated whether or not to write a review for Wishbone since it's been quite a while since I ate there, but I thought you deserved to know why I haven't been back.  My Dad's family is from Kentucky. My Mom's family is from Louisiana. I grew up on Southern food. For me Wishbone was a disappointment. It isn't that the food isn't good, but if you know Southern food I think you will be disappointed too. It ain't Mama's cookin'! I recommend you spend your hard-earned, discretionary, eatin' out money elsewhere.  The next time you're hankerin' for some Southern cookin', make yourself some collards or fry up some okra. Or wait 'til your next trip back South (hand over heart) and eat Mom's cookin' or dine at that local place... you know the one ... with the biscuits and the good grits ... and save me a seat, ya'll ... I'll be there directly.

Just had lunch here and it was really good. The service was good, the pulled pork was really good and the sides were good. What I like best about this place is that its very consistent. Over the years I have been here maybe 10-12 times and each time I leave saying that I will be back soon. It smells great and the environment is welcoming.

This Chicago icon is tried and true.  Eat in and see the who's who of Chicago leadership.  Use them for catering and get the same polite reliable staff every time.  Thank you for being such a solid institution in our family's life.

This place is a decent breakfast place. I usually get the North Carolina Style Crab Cakes for breakfast.  The crab cakes are meaty and flavorful.  The service is alright.  I've been here on weekends and it's always jam packed making it feel a little too tight for comfort.

This review is specific to Wishbone catering (and more specifically their wedding catering).  When my husband (then fiancé) and I started looking for a wedding caterer we SO overwhelmed.  Lets be honest, adding the label "wedding" to anything seems to instantly add an up charge.  We did not want to pay a lot of money for boring, run of the mill wedding food.  We came across Wishbone and thought that we should give it shot (since we love to have brunch there).  Wishbone (and Viri) was the perfect choice! We were able to pick a unique menu (apps; mini pulled pork sliders & black bean cakes.  Dinner; brisket, veggie hoecakes, asparagus, corn muffins, a gratin potatoes etc) at a reasonable price.  The quality of the food was excellent and we received a lot of compliments from our friends and family.  Our food was unique and most importantly it tasted good! Because our reception venue was BYOB Wishbone also provided us bartenders.  Wishbone organized table renters and wait staff.  They were always open to meeting with us and set up everything on the day of.  They were dependable on the day of and Viri was very detail oriented.  Our guests commented on how friendly the wait staff was too! I would advice, if you do decide to think outside of the box and go with Wishbone that you ask for Viridiana (Viri) working with her made all the difference.  We had an awesome wedding and certainly weren't worried about the catering.  (Thank  you Viri & Staff!)

I had a good time here. The atmosphere was very low key the service was just right and the food was good.  All the food was good.  It wasn't spectacular but good. We ordered mac-n-cheese, beef brisket, red beans & rice, pork chops, mashed sweet potatoes, crab cakes, collard greens, sauteed spinach, apple pie,and hell I don't remember everything . I can tell you that the only caveats to the food were:  the apple pie was lacking in flavor. It wasn't bad but it just could have been better, especially for a restaurant version. the pork chops could have been more tender(although quite tasty with an apple based coating) and the crab cakes although good, didn't have an authentic feel to them.  Don't go with extremely high expectations because you'll be disappointed. . Just go to give it a try. I'll be returning.
I hear the BBQ is good.  Like most of the meat places I go to, I'm pretty much just along for the ride.  This place has veggie options that are pretty decent.  Id go back.

This place was really good, but not spectacular. The decor, & atmosphere is great. My wife and I had a great seat on the patio, the weather was perfect and it's in a nice area of west loop. The food was really good. I had brisket taco's, which sounds like a sacrilege, but they were mighty tasty. They remind me of "street tacos", which are my fav. My wife had a burger which she enjoyed too. The food reminded me of some good home cooked barbecue, so don't expect anything fancy.  My only complaints are the wait staff could have been a little more attentive, it seemed like a very slow night when we went. Also, the side dishes were small. I got fried corn and peppers, and while it was delicious it was a very small portion. I would definitely recommend checking this place out!

We had brunch here the day after our wedding. They wouldn't take a reservation because they are so busy and we didn't want to plan a whole big event. It was totally fine, though, because they ended up seating all of our tables relatively close to one another, and most importantly, the food was delicious. Everyone in our large group loved their food and the various fresh-pressed juices. Great place for groups!

I know this isn't a burger joint...so maybe this is my fault.  But their house burger tasted exactly like something from a high school cafeteria - thin, rubbery with that boiled meat taste.  The sides were also mediocre at best.  I'd love it to be good since it's right next to my work, but it's not.  Spare yourself.

This was my second time here and I have to say I still wasn't really impressed.  I had the pulled pork and it was ok, nothing to brag about, I've had much-much better BBQ.  The sautted spinach was really good though, and the mac and cheese was just ok.  The other people in the party enjoyed their food, but no one was "too impressed" or disappointed. What really turned me off was the SERVICE.  The female server was really rude!  First, she didn't give us enough straws and when I asked for more, her facial expression was terrible and she looked on the table like we took the extra straws.   What really topped the cake is when I asked, what was in the "mashed sweet potatoes".  She respondended, "Umm, sweet potatoes" and then a long pause until I said, "yes I understand that, but is there anything else like brown sugar, butter, etc."  she said she didn't know.  Her response/tone was very off-putting and came across like I was ignorant and had asked a terrible question.  Really? I know there are sweet potatoes, so clearly I'm trying to dig further. At most places they often times mix in brown sugar and/or butter, etc.  The tone and facial expression was very insulting.  The other guests at the table were blown away by her tone as I held back from telling her about herself.  I was def. insulted.  She could tell from the tables vibe we caught on to her rudeness as everyones face was like "OMG-did she just respond to you like that?".  I was going to request a new server, but let it go, as there were friends from Germany visiting and I didn't want to make it an ordeal--but I was upset. :( Wont write the place off yet, will just try something else (and avoid this waitress). This was 7/11 around 6:15ish, Sat at the outside patio.

The first time I went to Wishbone was at the Lincoln Ave location. This time I went to the Washington Blvd one. The only thing I remember from my first visit were the collard greens, so I made sure to order them again. Also got the shrimp & grits, which I've heard about but never tried. It was decent, I liked the rich flavors and creamy texture. But I'd have preferred fewer but bigger shrimps, and they did not taste very shrimp-y. It also happened to be another 100deg day, so the grits were too heavy for the weather. The collard greens were as good as I remembered. Also liked the corn muffin (though friend pointed out they'd shrunk in size). Friend got crab cake which was quite tasty (not greasy at all, lots of real crab meat). It's a decent restaurant, but not something I'd eat regularly.

Wishbone was really fun. I am never in that part of Chicago, but if I ever am again I will definitely stop back by.  My friend & I were at the H2O+ warehouse sale & needed sustenance. We went to brunch & had a few drinks & a whole mess of sides. Grits! Biscuits! Succotash! Brunchy-drinks! Relatively reasonable and the food was good. Plus we were late enough there wasn't a line. Definitely want to go back for lunch

I've been here several times, largely because I apprecate the fact that they 1) have several veggie options and 2) allow you to hang out with your four-legged child in the outdoor seating area. Service has always been reasonably quick and friendly, the food is tasty, the adult beverage selection is good. A definite keeper.

Yelp says two stars equals "Meh.  I've experienced better."  That's pretty much exactly my sentiment so I'm going with that. I got the crab cakes Benedict and it was okay.  Not the most flavorful thing I've ever eaten but not the worst, either.  I asked for a corn muffin on the side because I wanted to try one.  The waitress informed me that would be an extra charge.  Okay, that's fine.  However, the muffin never came out.  She did take it off the bill, though. The service was slower than I would have expected but I think that's just our expectation of everything going super quickly.  Still, if you're in a hurry be aware. I tried one of their specialty juices and that was fine.  The best part of the whole meal, though, was the cheese grits!  YUM!  My dining partner agreed.  Her omelet was nothing special but the cheese grits definitely made the meal more tolerable. In summary:  food = hit or miss, service = hit or miss, prices = a little high for the quality Still, I'll probably be back at least one more time.

Always  the absolute MUST VISIT, must eat place for breakfast or brunch whenever I come to my hometown of Chicago. The food is so very tasty here and perfectly seasoned. Offers traditional breakfast favorites with a little twist. For example, my favorite meal there is the scrambled eggs, turkey bacon and BLACK BEAN CAKES! The corn muffins tops  off the breakfast and their amazing! A meal a Wishbone would be incomplete to me with out a signature drink here, MR. FUNKY!  Keep in mind this place closes at 3p and reopens for dinner at 5p. Always pretty crowded on weekends. Large open seating, sorta cafeteria style, but hipper"-) It's GO!! Make it happen the next time you are in Chicago. BTW, Oprah and her team ate here at least 3 times a week!

Friends brought me out for brunch last week. Can never decide among the corn pancakes with ham off the bone, salmon cakes benedict and wonderful sounding veggie burger they make. Went with my old stand-by, the crawfish cake benedict. They're a little spicy and come with the wonderful cheesy grits and baking powder biscuit--yum!. Of course, had half for breakfast the next day.  Friends tried to surprise me with free dessert--they know I have health issues--so the waitstaff gave me a choice, and still came out and sang to me with the delicious brownie in a pie shell--best of two worlds there. Anyway, Wishbone goes the extra mile! Only wish they offered the red cabbage cole slaw with brunch. It's available only with lunch and dinner.

FOOD POISON!!!  I never had food poiion in my life so I'm not crying wolf and I do not have a sensitive stomach (which wouldn't excuse it anyway) I eat everything and have been going to restaurants forever.  SORRY WISHBONE! but it's CONFIRMED that I had a stomach flu 4 hours after I left there. It says that a stomach virus starts from 4 hours to 48 hours directly after the contaminated food or water. Was there Tuesday 6/26 at 10 am. Ordered Lite spinach egg white omlette.  Had a tiny taste of the cheese grits and said ew! too salty. Put some mango chutney salsa on top of my omelette. Coffee and water and that'st it  - no bread or corn muffin, nothing.  At exactly 2pm, my stomach was hurting and I went to the bathroom...and went and went. Felt like I had the flu. Then diarrhea all day and night for the past two days. I'm on day 3 and I feel SLIGHTLY better. It also says that it doesn't have to be a group of people to get it, and it can only be one.  It was the first thing I ate all day and the day before was nothing but home made food which I have been eating for weeks. It's OFFICIAL! - otherwise, food was just alright..coffee was very good..service was alright.  For true brunch, there are MUCH better places all over Chicago.

Thought I'd swing by this place because it's near Harpo Studios.  I am so glad I stopped by!  After a tepid greeting my the hostess, I was waited on by a friendly guy who was very pleasant and attentive. The grub:  I ordered a house salad with the lemon dressing.  Salad was fine, but I had to trade the dressing for a more tasty honey mustard.  Waiter made the switch with a smile.  By the way, their dressings are homemade.  My entree was the buttermilk chicken breast, mac-n-cheese, cole slaw, and green beans.  It was slap ya mama AND kick ya grandma kinda good!  Except for the mac-n-cheese, which was dry, the flavoring was unique and I kept wanting to eat and eat and eat.  The homemade lemonade was huge, but mild in flavor.  I'm not a lover of corn muffins, but I ate theirs because they were set before me.  No complaints with those. I was not disappointed at all and will definitely go back.

Went to Wishbone's today for lunch and I really enjoyed it. I had the brisket with mac and cheese and collard greens. Everything was delicious! This was really the best brisket I have ever had. So tender it melted in my mouth.  My husband had the blackened Tilapia and it also very good. We will be back!

Wishbone is a popular soul food restaurant just west of the loop. I've been here a couple of times, and each time I left feeling the same that the food was just ok. After the first visit, it would not have been my choice to return, but I went with a group of co-workers who absolutely LOVE this place. Wishbone is always crowded and the service is slow, the flavor of the food was nothing to jump up and down about and  the portions are small. The food also does not come out hot, as if it has been sitting for awhile. I felt like I was eating leftovers. During my most recent visit I had the blackened catfish which came with cole slaw, corn muffin and two sides. For the sides I chose collard greens, and mashed potatoes. Each portion was about one scoop of everything which would've been ok if the prices matched the small portions. I probably won't be returning.

As a southerner and a vegetarian, I was thrilled to visit Wishbone. I was not let down! I went with a large group on a weekday for lunch. The service was fast and friendly, and they split a large bill between multiple credit cards without a fuss.  I got the vegetable platter with cheese grits, collard greens, and hoppin john. The beans were clearly fresh and maintained a bit of bite. The cheese grits had a sufficient amount of cheese but lacked spice. The collard greens tasted more like soul food collards than southern collards, but that's only problematic if you prefer the southern version. Once sufficient amounts of hot sauce were added the meal was perfect comfort food. The cornbread was the best part of the meal and I would recommend getting it to mix with the grits. Yum!

As far as breakfast places go, this one works for me. The food is good, the bloody marys zingy and the crowd is fun. The first time I went I had the Blackened Catfish (my first time), and I was very satisfied. I ended up eating half of my friend's Crunchy French Toast (also first time). Whoever thought to put corn flakes on french toast is a genius. Of course I had troubles walking home and the rest of the day but it's the price you pay I guess!

I mean, yeah, it's...on the ok side of good. The blackened catfish had a really good flavor, but it was a bit soggy for my liking. I was pretty disappointed in the cheese grits, as they were a congealed mass of jello-like substance, and did not taste like cheese at all. On another recent occasion, I got the corn cakes. Not bad. I've never had them so I'm not sure what they're supposed to taste like, but it was about what you'd expect from something called a "corn cake." The pieces of scallion and corn interspersed throughout gave them a really fun texture. The red pepper sauce that came with it was bland though, and tasted more like mayo or something than red pepper. But the maple links! Excellent!! Service is also hit or miss...I once had a very attentive server (did a great job), and another who wouldn't look me in the face (maybe my evil eye was out in full force that day). Either way, I'll probably go back once more.

Wishbone catered my wedding last weekend and they were AMAZING! I live in LA so planning a Chicago wedding could've been stressful. Luckily for me I found Wishbone! Viri and Reyna were so accommodating and really put me at ease. My fiance was unable to attend the tasting and Reyna brought him a plate of my choices to a friend's wedding that  Wishbone catered just so he could try the food! These extra touches really make all the difference when planning your big day! I had my wedding at Prairie Productions so in addition to booking a caterer I also had to bring in all the tables, chairs, linens ect...Viri handled it all! She coordinated the staff, food, set up and it all went off without a hitch! All my guests raved about the food and the service was excellent. The Catering CAptain Alejandro was a true professional and made sure that everything was perfect! I can't say enough good things about Wishbone and would recommend them to anyone! They will go above and beyond to make your day perfect!

Yelpers I am a fan of Wishbone.  Every chance we get at different restaurants we try to order some version of shrimp and grits.  And Wishbone did not disappoint.  From the smothered porkchops to the Hoppin' John to the blackened catfish we love pretty much everything they can make.  It is a wonderful reminder of southern cooking now that we live so far north in Chicago. Table service was great.  They do take reservations, and be sure to checkout their amazing website!  The design and graphics are the best I've ever seen.

All I can say is "wow"!  My beloved nephew and his beautiful new wife had their wedding reception at Wishbone last night, and everything was fantastic, but especially the so tasty food.  Hand carved brisket was smoky melt in your mouth with the crust I love, and the pulled pork was perfection.  The mac and cheese had a delicious thick melted cheesy crust, and rice and perfect warm corn muffins.  We had to dance like crazy after all the great food - it is a great venue for a wedding and everything could not have been better.

Great for a dinner with kids.  We were here last night with my 7 year old and she had a blast.  They had Tom & Jerry cartoons playing on the big screen, a good variety on the kids menu, so friendly and accommodating!  Our food was all very tasty and lots of families in the restaurant.  Easy street parking too.  If you are visiting Chicago and want a nice break from the Michigan Ave hustle and bustle, take a quick cab over here.  I live in the near west suburbs and definitely plan to be back very soon!

The following are the pros and cons from my first visit with my husband. We got eggs florentine, biscuits and gravy, and crab cakes during brunch, all to share. Pros: Cool items on the menu Crispy homefries (maybe even deep fried?) Pretty good corn muffin Cool interior They offer real maple syrup for an up-charge They discount for bikers They bagged our leftovers in some earth-friendly plastic Cons: A rather un-appetizing dog ("Wishbone") with crooked teeth plastered all over the place Home fries were not especially flavorful unless you scooped the few sautéed onions onto them, but there were not enough for this purpose Crab cakes were mediocre, which is an even bigger shame considering their price tag and the restaurant's theme. No crab lumps in them, just pulverized crab fibers wrapped around too-spicy bread goo without much additional flavor. The biscuits in the biscuits and gravy were fine, but not amazing - as in, you wouldn't probably want to scarf them UNLESS they were covered in sausage gravy. I had to ask for a refill on coffee after sitting with an empty cup for quite a while, which is just horrendous in a place that does breakfast. They gave me a little pitcher with about 10 ozs of cream in it even though I was the only one having coffee. This was promising for me, because I use a lot of cream, but as they only refilled my coffee once at my request, one of two things happened: 1) 9/10ths of the creamer went to waste, which is not at all earth-friendly; 2) they reused it for someone else's table after a quick chill. Either way, I am not happy with the result. They bagged our leftovers in plastic. Yes, I know I put this down as a pro above - a pro for the environment because it's recycled - but it's a con for me when my hot food gets stuffed into plastic so that it becomes a nice chemical soup. I say to this restaurant and every other restaurant packing plastic, KEEP IT AWAY FROM MY HOT FOOD, please. We didn't try the pancakes, but we got a peek at someone else's; they looked a little like tortillas, which I take it is not good. I'm giving it 3 stars because it is certainly worth a try and my cons are pretty picky, but in a city with so many restaurants to try, I wouldn't waste my time returning to a restaurant of this caliber unless I happen to be in the area wanting Southern food.

Brunch time in the West Loop. Wishbone is my favorite place for it.  It's a short walk.  We can get seated quickly (read as: get there before noon on a weekend).  They've got great Southern food.  And I don't have to deal with rules and getting yelled at early in the morning (looking your way Ina).   We recently went for brunch.  I missed out on seeing some of their signature breakfast items on the menu, which was pared down for the weekday.  Still, we had plenty to choose from.  Of course we both got the same Spinach omelette with mushrooms and tomatoes, egg whites and feta for the lady, full on eggy and cheddar here.  It came with cheese grits and a fantastic corn muffin.  I got a side of home fries with it as well.  You can swap out the grits for homies, or get some toast if you want to pass on the buttery perfection of the corn muffin as my skinny girl did.   Coffee and water was filled promptly and our server was on it and pleasant.  Solid food and service, just what we wanted.  In and out like a robbery.

Wishbone, an oldie but just an OK E.  I wish I could say goodie. When wishbone first opened years ago, you couldn't get me out of the place.  I made weekly trips for the shrimp and grits and weekend brunch stops after a night of night clubbin'.  Now here I am years later with a family of my own and I decided to take them there for a taste of what I once loved A LOT. Well needless to say, like most things, it's not as pretty, or tasty as it once was.  My husband was not really impressed with his crab cakes, my kids liked the pancakes though, and I once again had my old favorite, shrimp and grits.  I loved my food, but I'm sure if it was the taste for the food so much as it was me not wanting to look like an ass for recommending we go out of our way to stop in.  I may sneak back in when I get some mommy time, but doesn't look like the family will come back with me.  Three stars for the shrimp and grits and the pancakes. :(

Since Dixie kitchen in Hyde Park got closed, we were looking for a place with good southern food. Wishbone has very good food, good service even with a small wait staff, and very reasonable prices. We tried crawfish cake, blackened Tilapia, and blackened chicken. They were al  delecious. Will definitely go back.

Whenever in the neighborhood, the family and I have come to Wishbone for our morning breakfasts!  I've tried their Red Eggs and Omelet with potatoes and salsa (forgot the name) and both were good.  Flavor is on point and the right amount, not too much food, not too little.  Coffee is okay, and the service is has been good.  Look forward to coming here for lunch one day and trying their southern Louisiana themed food one day. In summary, good food, good service, okay prices.

We were in search of good food with a southern influence - so I thought of Wishbone.  I have always liked this spot, but was never a HUGE fan.  But the food we ate last weekend has moved me closer to a favorite.   Sausage gravy with biscuits, cheese grits, ham and eggs,  home fried potatoes, bacon -- it was all that. And, not a long wait with an 11 am arrival.  May have been lucky, though. I would caution the patron around the bottomless mimosa - there is just too much orange juice and the drink completely loses the intended taste profile and function.  Aside from that, order food and drink coffee.

Went straight from Midway to Wishbone. (Randolph St location). This is a ritual for us when in Chicago and the shrimp & grits were amazing as usual. Washed down with some beet/carrot/ginger juice and I was good to go. Ran into MJ as we were walking out which was pretty cool too.

Went with friends to brunch at Wishbone last weekend and really enjoyed it!  I'm from the south, so I was so excited to see the southern menu!  Grits in Chicago....who knew!  I had the Shrimp and Grits, which were awesome and I will be having again!   Everyone at our table enjoyed what they ordered for food and drinks. The service was a little slow, they never did refill our waters, which they could have.  Besides that we enjoyed it! Great change of pace for brunch!
Consistently decent service, good bloody marys, and good food.  Reasonably priced compared to other restaurants in the area.

Get here early, the line will be long.  This restaurant is a staple in the West Loop.  Starting off a Sunday with Red Eggs with cheese grits - - hits the spot.  The breakfast burrito is basically the same dish but the burrito is rolled up.  The Shrimp Grits are rich and decadent.  Add a spicy bloody mary and it's nap time!  You can't go wrong with anything on this menu.  All delicious.  Glad they are in my neighborhood in walking distance!!

I just recently moved back to Chicago after being gone for 5 years. On our first morning back in the windy city I decided to take my husband to breakfast at Wishbone. After all of these years it did not let me down, the breakfast was still just as memorable as it had been in the past. I ALWAYS get the catfish so I decided to change it up and went with the Red Eggs and they were excellent.  The even offer free wi-fi which is really good to know since our internet has not been hooked up yet and the atmosphere is excellent for getting a little bit of work done. I see a bad review on here recently and I'm shocked, everything is homemade and the menu even says that it's $1 extra for 100% Maple Syrup. Which I do not necessarily agree with charging, however it is indicated on the menu. My husband had the Chicken Sausage Hash (which I of course tried) and it was full of flavor and we both loved it. We use hot sauce on everything and this did not need it at all.  My only complaint is that they use a vinegar based hot sauce and I'm not a fan at all. They again make their own so they should expand to include us hot sauce fans that don't do vinegar.

Like Denny's, but worse. I cannot believe this place has a 20 minute wait for a table, much less so many positive reviews on Yelp. I guess it has a kitsch factor that appeals to my fellow West Loop yuppies -- $10 pancakes made out of Bisquick mix. My fiance had a chicken sausage hash which had no flavor at all. None. My French toast was served with a side of not maple syrup, but the fake stuff Aunt Jemima makes. It was also cold. The potato home fries clearly had been frozen for a very, very long time and looked actually dehydrated.  And this all might be okay if the place was cheap, but it wasn't. Our bill including tip came to $31. I'd much rather have spent that money at Meli or Le Peep.

Sometimes I just have to have the Hoppin John and sweet tea at Wishbone.  Taste just like Mom's.  Great southern cooking with wonderful sides (the mashed sweet potatoes with pecans on top.)  Homey and easy-going.  A favorite in the West Loop.

love + the food is delicious for the price! (had the light spinach omelet - exactly what I was craving!) + casual atmosphere + seating indoors & outdoors cons - it's often super packed...(while we were there, and according to my friend) - service could be better in terms of checking up on us, we had to get her attention to get cream for coffee .. but that may be due to the fact that it was super packed. i would go again for breakfast/brunch!

A friend of mine came into town and was talking about wanting to get some good Cajun food. I said, "I know just the place." Wishbone. I had been there a few times with family and absolutely loved it. We put on our coats and braved a cold as all hell Chicago day and headed to the West Loop. The staff is very friendly and the whole place has an awesome decor. Tons of cool pictures and random stuff on the walls.  The young lady I was with got the Jambalaya Cajun Stew. It was really, really, good. I definitely snagged a few spoonfuls of that when she wasn't looking. She also ordered a side order of Black Eyed Peas, which were pretty good. I got the Blackened Cat Fish. It was probably the best cat fish I had ever had before. There were no bones and the whole thing was very well seasoned and overall it was great. It came with a piece of corn bread, which was very sweet and had real pieces of corn in it. I also had an order of Collard Greens & the cheezy grits. Both really tasty.  Definitely will be coming back and trying out something new because I know I won't be disappointed.
this palce is fab. wonderful food, interesting pictures, good prices.  can't do better than that!

Love this place! One of the few places in Chicago that I can eat a true vegan breakfast without any "fake" protein substitutes.  I always get their black bean cakes for breakfasts and am always given the option to replace the eggs with another side.  As for the sides, I love their fresh fruit and homemade sweet mashed potatoes. I  only wish that other Chicago restaurants would follow their lead and offer more vegan breakfast options.  Also I love that they have movie night for kids although I do not have them.

I wrote a review for the Wishbone on Lincoln and it pretty much sticks for this place as well. The only thing is the space in here isn't as warm and comfortable.  I decided to order something different this time around and I had the smoked brisket hash. It smelled AMAZING and it was pretty tasty. My issue was the temperature. I'm not sure if they made it first and forgot to put it under a heat lamp but it was kinda cold. It was still pretty good and the service was great as well.

Shrimp grits: amazing! I don't even like shrimp! Prices were relatively reasonable, but I kept my fooding to a bellini & the shrimp grits. I'm a breakfastaholic though, so if it's good breakfast I'll think it's amazing.  Good, good.

A friend met me at Rush U Medical today, hungry and eager to eat. I suggested a few good places for breakfast in the Greektown/W Loop area. Her eyes lit up and she said, "Wishbone, there's one around here? I've been meaning to try the one on Lincoln Ave..."  It's been many years since I been to the one in the Roscoe Village/W Lakeview neighborhood. I was actually glad she chose a place I had never been before.  The entrance will deceive you. It's the third door from the right. It would be helpful if a sign was posted on the second door to direct you. Instead, it's like something right out of the Safe House Restaurant in Milwaukee, WI. You become the entertainment for those sitting in the dining room who can see you contemplating the doors. I ordered the Red Eggs. I guess no one calls it Juevos Rancheros anymore.  It's as good as I remember what scrambled eggs (you get two, cooked your way) on corn tortillas with cheese, chili ancho sauce, scallions, sour cream and salsa taste like. I asked for mine to come without black beans (you can leave them in if you want) and added hot sauce. My girl friend ordered the Blackened Catfish which comes with coleslaw, corn muffin and her two side choices of cheese grits and mac & cheese. She enjoyed it. She did whisper that she prefers the Quaker Oats instant grits. I don't want to ever try grits. Sounds like sand to me.

I met a friend here for brunch after church and it did not disappoint. I am a southern girl so sometimes I find myself comparing the North and the South. I am a slight Southern Princess and I like what I like *teehee*. Anywho, I was super excited when I saw that I could actually get CHICKEN andouillie sausage. That is something you do not find in the south, but I could not be happier. This dish was spicy, filling but not overly, with chicken, potatoes, green and red peppers, and onions. It was wonderful. Let's not forget the cornbread muffin which was tasty! My friend ordered the shrimp and grits and swears by it (refer to Will E.'s review). I did not try it but I am sure to go back and explore the menu! A bonus that the service was great and our food came out pretty fast!

Wishbone is hands down my favorite place in Chicago!!! The Shrimp & Grits is the best dish on the menu (sans the bacon) and is served in a nontraditional manner. Conventional thinking would have you believe grits & shrimp should be served on a plate and separated from one another via a scoops but Wishbone's Shrimp 'n Grits....WOW! The dish is served in well...a dish! Served in a bowl with the shrimp buried within and seasoned to perfection. The cheese is strewn throughout the dish and melted. Accouterments include mushrooms & scallions with white wine and cream over cheese grits...O.M.G. Ladies and gentlemen if you don't order anything else on the menu and never plan to visit Wishbone again order the Shrimp & Grits!! The pancakes are good and the crunchy french toast is lovely meld of sweet and crunchy meets savory. Nice! But I can't tell you enough about the Shrimp & Grits. I have been here a few times; several times in the same trip! and each time I order I crave, absolutely crave the Shrimp & Grits. It has been a week since my last visit and as I type this review I am thinking about recreating the dish in my kitchen until my next trip to Chicago's West Loop. Top off your breakfast with a smoothie - mix up to three flavors - and start your day off in pure bliss!!

I recently went for brunch on a Sunday and loved it.  The atmosphere is great, the service was superior and the food was great.  We took some out of town friends and we all had different dishes and everyone loved their meal.

I was in the area because I went to the Rosie Show at Harpo Studios.  This place is about a block down the street. I thought this restaurant had it all - the ambiance, the service, the food - all wonderful.  And they had so many vegetarian and vegan options for me to choose from! Had the black bean cakes with mac & cheese and spinach.  Hubby had the rainbow trout with a lemon sauce (a special of the day) with zucchini and mashed sweet potatoes. I had the mango salsa with the black bean cakes and really enjoyed the flavor. The other option was red pepper sauce which looked to be mayo-based.  I adored the mac & cheese, so excellent I would come back just for a big bowl of it as my entree. Hubby found a few bones in the trout, other than that, it was outstanding.   Only minor complaint is the cornbread muffin that was served with the meal was not great - a bit on the dry-side.  An added bonus was that the service was fantastic.  I'll be back.

Star Light Star bright, The first star I see tonight, I wish I may, I wish I might, Have the wish I wish tonight. I really, really, really wish that Wishbone would just be more awesome. In theory, I should live Wishbone.  Southern food.  You can make reservations online via Open Table.  Breakfast for dinner! Sadly, I'm just not that DTF with Wishbone. While the Wishbone outpost on Lincoln is downright abysmal, the West Loop location is not as terrifying.  My party of 8 had our table set and ready when we walked in the door (Thanks Open Table!).  Wishbone politely offers up complimentary mini cornbread muffins on the table while you wait for your food, and I honestly think they're the best part of the meal.  I swear to God, they use bacon fat or something in those muffins!  Drink orders were taken quickly and I got down to menu perusal business. Sigh.  Nothing really sang to me on the dinner menu, so I decided to go for broke and eat breakfast for dinner.  I mean, I'm definitely not above an omelet past noon, so I decided on the light spinach omelet (egg whites, spinach, tomatoes and mushrooms with your choice of cheese), hash browns and toast. When my omelet came it looked very pretty, but was tragically missing the cheese.  In hindsight, it was probably for the best.  It kept my entree incredibly low cal so I felt way less guilty tearing into the hash browns, but still... Not what I ordered and the flavor definitely lacked.   One thing I can say is that while our server was a little on the odd side of normal, he was incredibly attentive.  So there's that.  Good job, buddy. Street parking if you can find it, otherwise valet.
Think I saw Rosie O eating here!  First time eating here and was very happy with food and service.  Not a "blackened" food fan but found other great choices...

If you love breakfast and brunch and you love Eggs Benedict, you're doing yourself a disservice not trying it here!  Just walking from the entrance to our table, 8 trays with at least one order of Eggs Benedict passed by. Just from the smell alone, the visit was worth it.  Service was a little hit and miss, and the place was pretty full for a 12:30 on a Saturday. I had to flag down the waiter repeatedly in order to get a coffee refill.  I'd go here again, but would definitely be doing what I can to avoid peak service times based on the wait experience.

I always make sure I go here when I'm back in Chicago. We had the crabcakes and bacon omelet and were not disappointed. Wishbone is great because the food doesn't taste like a restaurant's interpretation of home-cooking, it tastes like HOME-COOKING! Mr. Funky is my favorite brunch booze, and the waiter was very personable.  I also have to give the owner a shout-out. We met him at the Wishbone booth at the North Coast Music festival and he was incredibly sweet. Great food and great folks. Highly recommend.

Went over the summer.   We sat outside - beautiful day out so no problem with that.  The waitress just seemed really distracted, however she was very pleasant and nice. The food was good.  We went more for breakfast/brunch food. I ate GOOD.
Overall It was good. The service fantastic, although the food was just OK

Was here on Sunday morning for our weekend brunch ritual. We were seated inside immediately. It is a fairly big place, and it was crowded but there was no waiting time. The decor and atmosphere are ok. I ordered the Kentucky scramble with wheat toast and cheesy grits. It was great. I loved the scramble, it was seasoned well. The grits was a new side for me, I have never tasted southern food. I really liked it and it was a nice change from the usual potatoes. Hubby ordered the black bean cakes with red pepper sauce, house potatoes, sautéed spinach and toast. Now I think one of us should have got the corn muffin instead of the toast. Oh well,  next time! The black bean cakes were really moist and tasty, but I expected the red pepper sauce to be more flavorful, it was alright. House potatoes were really good. The good thing is food is not very greasy, which is always a very good thing acc. to me. The service was ok, not bad not great. All in all, an interesting enough place that I would like to come back to.

I was very excited when I was recommended Wishbone as a catering service for our wedding reception. I like the restaurant and was looking forward to the possibility of supporting a local business. However, I am extremely disappointed with the way they handled my inquiry. After a phone conversation with Reyna about the details, I was told that it would take 2-3 weeks to recieve a proposal. I patiently waited over 3 weeks and then followed up with a phone call and message. After several more weeks went by, I called again and spoke with another staff member who said she would check in with Reyna and one of them would get back to me. No one EVER returned my call. My originally conversation with Reyna was 7 months ago, and I have obviously wrote them off. If you are looking for quality service for any event, I strongly recommend considering anywhere but Wishbone Catering!

Wishbone is by far, my favorite breakfast eatery in Chicago.  From their blackened catfish to the breakfast burrito with ancho chili sauce, they never disappoint.  Although crowded at times, due to it's popularity, they always do their best to get you seated and served quickly.  The quality of their food is always consistent, served hot and fresh.  Try a side of cheese grits or seasoned home potatoes with your entree.

Very cool place. Good southern style breakfast food that's more then the typical Chicago brunch place. I went to school the south so the southern eggs benedict and sweet tea reminded me of a place I used to call home.

1. Worst mac and cheese ever. so gross.  2. frozen burgers prior to being cooked = tastes like cardboard 3. no french fries 4. I don't want to eat a side item that has a name attached-- "hoppin john, hoppin jack" 5. the managers are dressed like teenagers. where is the professionalism?

I don't get it. I know good food. My palate is pretty good. This place wasn't good at all. 1st- It's a kid friendly restaurant with no kid like food? My family hit this place up for breakfast one weekend. My daughter was forced to eat some type of cornbread muffin type thing (can't remember) and dry pancakes. I had the crab cakes (after searching forever on the menu for something I'd like) and I can't remember what he had. I think his plate was something he was satisfied with. Anyways, 2 stars because the service was great and quick considering it was a Sunday morning. I left hungry.

The food was all right but was extremely oversalted. refills on water are non existant. Our coffee wasn't refilled until we pulled over a busboy and asked him for more.  we waited at our table for ten or fiften minutes before someone even talked to us. Our waiter paid little to no attention to us. They added extra things on to the bill that we had to fix. And, when the menu says ".50 cents extra to add additional items to omlete, they really mean to add certain things to the omlette. I'm sure there's plenty of place to get brunch. This is not one of them

meh, Last couple of times I have had dinner here, it seems as though the quality of food has been going down. The brunch is great. Breakfast burrito is a must, plus their fresh squeezed juices especially lemonade is great. The waitstaff is always nice and helpful. It just seems as thought the last couple of times I have been here, I will try something new, (fish) and it doesn't seem fresh, and isn't seasoned much. I usually stick with the BBQ or meatloaf, but even the last couple of times I have seen it, it doesn't look like it has been made with as much love as it was before ;(

I've been here several times.  It is incredibly crowded when the weather is nice, but once in a while (usually late afternoon) - you can find a table easily and sit outside - that I LOVE.  Most recently, I dined with four adults, a toddler and three children between 10-12.  It was great, but the wait was unacceptable - but keep in mind that the Rock n Roll Marathon was the same day (don't ask why I was not in it - maybe next year?). Our server was a little *distant*, but the place was packed and I could tell he was doing the best he could.  The greeters were as pleasant as pie.  Food - could have been hotter (but I despise luke warm food - so it could be me) and I would love it if they switched up the menu more frequently.  All in all - a great casual place to hang with friends and catch up.

I keep trying to like Wishbone, but it just keeps disappointing. Recent weekday lunch service was TERRIBLE. Everything was super slow (1.5 hours for a business lunch - not including the trip to/from the restaurant is not okay). The server was also kind of gross. She had somehow cut herself and got blood on the napkins she handed us, offering up just an offhanded, "Oops, I'm bleeding everywhere," and giving us the napkins anyway. Ew. Then we watched her run her hands through her hair before grabbing another table's tray of food to deliver to them. Also, a couple of people in our party had their food missing odd elements, like they forgot to put cheese on top of one dish (standard part of the dish), etc. And, as usual for me at Wishbone, the food all sounds good, but comes out pretty mediocre. I think I'm done giving this place chances.

We went here for lunch on Friday after taking my grandpa to his doctor's appointment at NMH.  I was happy to be spending time with my family and was looking forward to meeting my aunt at one of her favorite restaurants.   Man was I dissapointed.  My family behaved.  It was the food that was a let down.   I knew I was in trouble when I had a hard time finding something on the menu that sounded good.  I settled on the crab cakes and got mac and cheese and hopping john on the side.  The crab cakes had ok flavor but a mushy texture.  The mac and cheese had no cheese flavor and the hopping john was just ok.  Oh.  The meal also came with cole slaw.  It was inedible.  Because I was in public I didn't think I should spit it into my napkin.  But, man, I wanted to!  The corn bread muffin is ok.  But, I personally like my jiffy corn bread better. Some other highlights?  The service is slow, it is very loud, and I had a stomach ache for the rest of the day.    I am hoping I don't have to come back.

Wishbone, I wish I had liked you four stars worth, I really do.  I came with great expectations.  My sister loves it and chose it for the perfect place to bring my 89 year old father after his doctor appointment at Northwestern.  Maybe food wise but not ambiance wise.   If it is the right choice for him, was I really going to like it?  Ambivalence abounds followed by dashed dreams, much like when you are clutching onto the wishbone and hoping...hoping you get the bigger piece and...you don't.  Darn it! I ordered the brisket plate with mac n cheese and Hopping John.  Both were ok.  The coleslaw wasn't worth eating and the brisket was good but boy, I have had much much better.  The corn bread was outstanding however.   The service?  There was a person who took orders and delivered food but other than that, not much service.  Extremely slow at every point.  The restaurant was also extremely loud which made conversation very hard.   Ignore my quick tip, not a good place to take your Dad.  Maybe I will try again for breakfast?

Wishbone has been going strong at this location for what seems like forever.  The menu is huge, the portions are fair, the food is authentic and the outdoor seating is awesome.  If you like Southern/Cajun food and you are in the West Loop, you need to hit up Wishbone.   My personal favorite is the Shrimp & Grits with a Carrot/Beet/Apple juice.

I've eaten here numerous times over the past decade, and the food is consistently good.  Many vegetarian options, and good sized portions. The cornbread muffins are from heaven. I love the red eggs as well.  The southern eggs benedict is a mega-caloric guilty pleasure that says "clean your plate, I dare you".  This place can be mega-slammed on the weekends, it is the nature of popular brunch spots in a large city.   They usually handle that pretty well.  When it's slammed it can be noisy, otherwise the noise level is average. I had a sad face when they closed the Berwyn location which was much closer to me, but this place ain't so bad to get to for me.  This is a place I would be happy to take anyone, out of towners or locals.  I loves me some wishbone.

Breakfast was fantastic which lead me to believe the lunch would follow suit. Unfortunately I was let down. If I come back I will definitely stick to the breakfast menu. The service was a bit lacking on a moderately busy day for lunch. For breakfast I went with the North Carolina Style Crab Cakes. The blue claw patties were warm and crispy topped with lemon butter sauce accompanied by two eggs, seasoned home fires and toast. A great deal and everything was awesome on the plate.  Flash forward a couple weeks for lunch. Blackened Catfish Po' Boy was a good alternative to chicken or beef. It was slathered with spicy remoulade on french bread. Served with Yankee coleslaw. Sounds like a plate full right? Wrong, it looked as if there might have been something missing (see picture). The sandwich was great, the slaw was limp and off putting. I just wanted a little more with a sandwich, like a side of fries I didn't have to order off the "Sides" menu. Maybe that's what you have to do. The service was full of up-selling attempts but I wasn't that hungry for much more than I ordered. Water glasses sat half full of ice and remained unattended on a hot ass day.  So I have to give the breakfast egg-sperience 4 stars but lunch barely earned 3 stars. They have a nice outdoor patio and a large menu. A dish to suit everyone's needs but you may end up wishing for more.
Great food. Great service. Nice atmosphere! Kinda average food, but still good!

Was in Chicago for a friend's birthday party so a group of us went here on Sunday for breakfast before we departed for our respective cities. There were 9 in our group and we were seated right away. A few people in my group ordered the shrimp and grits and said it was the best they've ever had. I had the blackened catfish and it was excellent. The drinks were good as well...we had Mimosa's and Bloody Mary's. Service was great....our waiter was very prompt and we never had any issues. Will definitely visit this place again on my next trip to Chicago.

i LOVE Wishbone!!! I HAD to come here on my bday on this past Saturday.. shout out to all the Cancers in the house! I had the Jambalaya omelette.. O M G!!! I definitely recommend that entree, amazing!  The service was great, we sat outside on the patio, and the weather was perfect. Good place to eat, and people watch.  I will definitely come to this place again, and again!  oh! Try the mimosas.. they are great!

three words.... CRAWFISH CAKES & CORNBREAD!!! CRAWFISH CAKES & CORNBREAD!!! CRAWFISH CAKES & CORNBREAD!!! 'nuff said... (did i mention the crawfish cakes were outstanding?  and the homemade cornbread - always warm when it comes to the table - when slathered with butter, is AWESOME!!!
It's a good southern place and food is not bad but I'm always weirded out like it's so informal I feel I'm at a warehouse lol At least you have to try it for yourself and the food IS actually good.

I went to Wishbone for the first time on Saturday.   Went to catch up with an old friend.  We were able to get a table outside.  Although I hear there was some attitude when we asked to sit in the shade.  The food was good.  I ordered the red eggs.  Sounded interested.  My friend had the Crunchy French Toast which she loved.  Everything was ok except for the service.  Very slow and our server was OVER THE TOP.  Usually, I love friendly servers but this lady was a step above obnoxious.  She sang loudly in french to a child sitting next to us, would scream from a few feet away to see if we needed anything.  Just weird.
no matter how much you order, you HAVE to get biscuits and gravy. that is all i have to say. =)

TUESDAYS! Why a family with kids would eat anywhere else on Tuesday is a mystery to me: Cartoons keep the kids occupied, & the kids' menu is free. (I think it's one free kid per adult, as we are, but I'm not sure.) I love the Hoe Cakes, & would eat here anyway. Food I actually love, cheaper than eating at home, come on! See you Tuesday.

I've been here during the week several times with coworkers. I was surprised that the southern inspired restaurant offered an egg white omlette with the choice to have pan spray instead of oil. Very impressed! and delicious! The only part that is not good is they close at 3 on Mondays.

Food was good, portions were small, service was slow, but at least you didn't have to wait for a table on a Saturday morning. The best biscuits and gravy is definitely here. I would go definitely go back and feel I may have just visited here on a "off" kind of day.

I love Wishbone! It is one of a few restaurants I consider a go-to emergency eatery as well as a place to intentionally plan dinner. There seems to be something for everyone--vegans/vegetarians as well as confirmed carnivores, health food enthusiasts as well as comfort food cravers, and mildly-seasoned items in addition to hot & spicy entrees. I can't imagine anybody who would walk in here, look at the menu, and be unable to find a single thing to eat. You also get an insane amount of food here, friendly service, and non-scary bathrooms. The sweet tea floweth into your cup, the smoothies are made with real fruit and not syrupy crap, and there are specials every day. My order always comes out right, my mango salsa is always fresh, and my belly is always full when I leave. I must, however, hold back on the fifth star for now, much as I might like to award it to Wishbone. The menu sometimes labels things as vegetarian or vegan, but not other times. There are things that sound like they would obviously be vegetarian but actually aren't because they are made Southern style, and some things that sound like they'd have animal products in them but don't. This is fine if your staff can answer a diner's questions about what is in the food on the menu. Unfortunately, some of the wait staff don't know much about the menu and on one occasion couldn't tell me what an Orange Julius even is besides "something with orange juice in it." (I realize I should know this myself, but cut me some slack--I couldn't even drink OJ for five years!) I think either the menu needs some handy little "V" symbols or the staff need to learn the menu (preferably the latter since people with food allergies  or gluten intolerance will not necessarily be helped by a "V" symbol). Despite this one big flaw, Wishbone is pretty great. I see myself continuing to eat here for as long as they keep up the good work.

I've done take out twice here and been inside for lunch twice also. But enough is enough. Ixnay on wishbone. The service here is painfully slooooow. These visits were on weekdays mind you. Me standing in line for Wishbone on weekends? Huh? As if! Girl you MUST be crazy. My order was wrong the last time I went and there were many apologies but meh.... The food here isn't even worth it, while the crunchy french toast was decent- I wouldn't go out of my way for it. Do not order the chicken sausage, it's dry and nothing special. I regretted taking the time to chew and swallow that. Home fries? Sucks. It's dry and it's just potato wedges with some onions. Mac and cheese? That sucked even more. Flavorless, and sad. Greasy, not cheesy. Good thing I can be flexible with my time on lunch because I would have been late after going here. If you're looking for breakfast around here, I'd rather go to the palace grill. At least they don't mess around there. The Shame.   NEXT!

I love brunch. I really really love brunch. It's by far my favorite meal and I never turn down a brunch invitation, so when people invited me I was all in. The place was good; service and food wise. Plenty to choose from so there is something for everyone. I'd like to go back and try some of the not so standard brunch options :)

*****5 STARS!!!!****** I want to PERSONALLY THANK Reyna and her outstanding staff who catered our event yesterday at the South Shore Cultural Center! OMG! The food was Marvelous, out-of-this-World!!!! Everyone ...including the Minister was thrilled!!! Nothing but accolades for your outstanding efforts! When I called, Reyna handled whatever I needed without fail!!! Event planners....call Wishbone -Chicago Catering!!! Reyna!!! You go Girl! I'll be calling again...SOON!!! Thank you ALL! My family and I have adopted you! Gailmarie Wooten-Ward

I was here for a fundraiser.  It was pretty good.  I can't really speak to the service because we had a buffet and the only one serving was the guy carving the meat - he was friendly enough.  Everything on the buffet was good - I'm not a huge fan of Southern cooking but Wishbone is decent.  I'd go back to try ordering off the menu.

I've only been here twice for lunch and both times ate wondering why people rave about this place. Service was extremely slow and not very friendly. The food was just OK.  Maybe I'll try the breakfast menu if I'm ever in the area.

What a great place for breakfast! We had to wait a bit for a table, but it was a Sunday around noon and the wait wasn't that long.  I had the Kentucky-style eggs with bacon and rye toast and potatoes....I am usually one to try something a bit different but I was nursing a hangover so simplicity won. My company enjoyed the shrimp & grits, craw-fish cakes, and eggs Benedict Florentine. I loved that the good wasn't too greasy, even the potatoes, and they were seasoned nicely. They also enjoyed Bloody Marys and "French Sparkle" cocktails (which included orange juice, champagne and vodka). I just could not do booze that day so I chose a virgin screwdriver. Also known as orange juice. Out server was quick and attentive...despite the near-collision with the guy who was bringing out our food on one arm. A couple of us nearly wore shrimp & grits and eggs Benedict, but it was a good save!  They kind of pack you in (any table on the floor, it was difficult not to be bumped or shoved by wait-staff, passers-by, and people from neighboring tables every so often), but this is the kind of place I'd love to have in a nearby neighborhood myself. Excellent for the morning after a night of drinking and ten times better than Ram's Horn or Denny's.

Wishbone is my favorite breakfast spot in Chicago, and I've frequented this location since the mid-90s.  As a host of the Chicago(ish) Tweetup, I've been able to secure reservations for large parties for breakfast on little to no notice, and Wishbone staff have accommodated us nearly every time (though at 'party of 70' they could not--understandably. They offered a fixed menu, but we opted to split into smaller groups).  No matter how crowded this place gets or how large our party (within reason), the service is always friendly, fun, and courteous. There is often a wait on weekends, but that's to be expected and in my opinion, the service is outstanding given the number of people this location serves every weekend. The food is Southern inspired, not true Southern; I know this is a sticking point for some people. Items to not miss: mimosas/bloody Marys for weekend brunch, the mochas served in a pint glass, the corn muffins (get a few to go--you won't be sorry), the cornflake-encrusted French Toast and the Yankee scramble.

A pretty sweet, southern brunch hot spot with your average brunch items and a lot of charm. The bloody mary was only so so, but I think we all agreed that our dishes were hearty and pretty decent. I think the cheesy grits was the winner at the table. Most of the other dishes didn't stand out too much, but we were thankful that the dishes weren't too greasy.  A good place for large groups.

I've been coming here since I was 4.  I haven't been that age for 2 decades.  This is a great spot for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, and I take friends here when they're visiting from out of town. Some of my favorites include: crunchy french toast, crawfish cakes, blackened blue fish (when they have it on special), the spring salad, the egg dishes for breakfast, black bean cakes, and I always get sauteed spinach. The staff is great, and for the most part they know how to pour wine.  They're super friendly and if you need anything they will make sure that you leave happy and full.   So go- you will not be disappointed!
YUM YUM YUM. The new buffett is so-so. Cheapens the quality of food a bit. But you can just eat from the menu and be ok!

We went for the cafeteria style dining.  We asked for some free samples before we picked our plate.  It took awhile to make a decision.  The downsides... the food was cold and flavorless - which was a huge disappointment because hellloooo its supposed to be NOLA inspired.  The beef brisket sandwich... was just okay... the bun was soft.  It felt like we were eating yesterday's left overs.  Barry had the chocolate pecan pie which he regretted.  Overall the meal was really unsatisfying.   Positives:  there was a table of really adorable elderly people who may or may not made me tear up from their cuteness.  Also because it was cafeteria style, we didn't have to tip!

I found a great alternative to Lou! Haha, I went here on a cold morning, expecting very little and came out pretty happy with what I had. Though I do not understand the term of "Southern Reconstruction" food, I do enjoy it a lot.  I had the breakfast crawfish cakes, these tiny cakes were filled with hearty chunks of crawdads were yummy, but did go on the chewy side. Probably since I came around the time of transition from breakfast to lunch. The Eggs were good, the waitress said they made them 14 different ways, I would have liked to know, but she was busy. I also had a huge biscuit which was amazing along with cheese grits.  So much southern goodness I skipped lunch! Definitely coming back, and maybe check out there dinner cafeteria style, should be good for a college crowd when they hear "a la carte"

I don't understand how this is always so packed.  I think it is just because there is no other place to go in the area with that much seating.  Omelet is dry, eggs benny is over cooked.   I would rather go to denny's.  Ok, the only plus is their bar but really not looking for a bar after a rough night, well maybe sometimes.
Best affordable Brunch and Lunch ever! Perfect post-Oprah show spot. Shrimp and grits were amazing! Mac and cheese is to die for!!

Wishbone is a refreshingly pleasant dining experience.  The staff is happy smiling and attentive while the food is equally pleasing. They have a great brunch on the weekends, the shrimp and grits is one of my favorites.
The food is okay - nice casual atmosphere and wait staff was always nice from what I remember.  There are a couple of interesting items on the menu.  Good for breakfast/brunch.

try the shrimp and grits it is the best thing on the menu! steak is under seasoned, crab cakes are soggy, and the service is terrible! the waitress forgot to put in the order for one of my guest and when the bill came they charged us 18% gratuity when we clearly didn't have enough people for gratuity.

I went here on a Sunday morning after mass at Old St. Pat's.  This place is great.  We had very good service.  The coffee is the best coffee I have had at a breakfast place (it was Irish coffee).  I had the wishbone omelet with potatoes, onions, cheese and salsa (l loved it, very tasty).  I chose the grits and corn muffin as my sides.  I have to say that I made awesome choices.  The muffin was so moist, I did not need to put any butter on it.  My mom had pancakes, and my goodness they melt in your mouth.  Even the spinach had a great taste.   This place is so clean.  I am a freak about cleanliness so I can tell!   Also, I enjoy the clientele.  Very nice group of individuals.  This place attracts and administers warmth and kindness. Very good aura.

Been coming for years (3-4 times/year). The place that turned me on to eggs scrambled w/cream cheese and cheese grits (raised below Mason Dixon but lived 40+ years w/o grits). Great menu options for veggie folks. Always consistent food & service - breakfast, lunch or dinner. Good ole standby in West Loop even if Oprah is leaving the hood.

Perfectly adequate brunch.  Great patio.  All ruined by the AWFUL service.  The wait staff here could care less.  They're pretty much indifferent, almost to the point of being mean.  I prefer my eggs without attitude, thank you.  I'll continue to keep walking past Wishbone to hit up Le Peep.

I came here last night for a friend's birthday, which was her restaurant choice. I'm a vegetarian, and she actually consider looking for vegetarian options when finding a restuarant for her birthday. Awesome friend.  I ordered the Vegetarian Hoe Cake with a side of Home Fries (I looooove potatoes). My food was alright, didn't think it was anything special though. A couple of my other friends ordered the fish, and another black bean patties.  Our server was really nice throughout the whole night, and very helpful. We thought he was flirting with one friend too lol... haahah The whole staff seem very friendly and warm.  I wouldn't want to go back and order something else, maybe breakfast next time.  Overall, a very friendly and pleasant experience.

I love breakfast.  I am a simple breakfast person though. I like scrambled or over-easy a side of white toast and a lot of butter, bacon and OJ. I also like strawberry crepes and plain maple syrup on my pancakes. I never try all of these other things but after reading these reviews I will. The only thing I don't like is potatoes wedges. I want hash browns, it's like when you go on vacation to Cancun and they have potato wedges for breakfast, lunch and dinner. What about hash browns or fries or baked potato? I've been here several times. It's good I like the feel inside and outside. One time I was sitting outside, eating breakfast and Obama walked across the street right towards me and I was like. hmm this guy is familiar.  Then he was right next to me and the table across the way were taking pictures with him.  Then I was like oh yea that's Barack Obama.  I believe he was done filming at Harpo while he was senator.  True story.

Like Britney Spears' Daddy says.."Grits is an old southern tradition -- my baby's been eatin it since she's been born, loves em. I don't have no sprinkle cheese, so I'm just puttin her mama's old-timey way here, doing it with some Velveeta in it." Unlike Britney Spears' Dad Wishbone uses white wine & cream and real cheese in their grits..and I gotta tell you the grits are what keep me comin' back for more! I don't think I've ever tried grits before coming to Wishbone, but it's a yummy side if you're looking for something different than homefries to go with your eggs. The Crunchy French Toast is also really tasty from the brunch menu..but if you're feeling like eggs for breakfast definitely go w/ one of the egg dishes b/c "one egg pan cooked" is $4.95 (what the hail?!) Great spot for brunch, but also a good place for dinner too if you're looking for some good comfort food. Ooh & the best part is that they serve shrimp & grits not only for brunch but on the dinner menu too! Also it's a good place to dine if you're looking for somewhere w/ a decent price & you have a larger party..it's a pretty big space & I've never had to wait long to get seated here.

Went here for brunch this morning. I was plain and opted for the regular pancakes, but they did not disappoint.
