I asked for my syrup to be heated (most places give me grief about this ...) and our server was happy to do so. The fiancé ordered the corn cakes with the chicken sausage - YUM. The red pepper sauce that comes with them is great. My gripe with this place was more about the hostess - she told us the wait would be 10 minutes. We waited... and when another table of 2 came in, she asked them, "Would you like to sit on the patio? Yes? Okay, right this way." It would have been nice if we were given this option 15 minutes ago... Grrrr.
Wishbone in West Loop is great stop for breakfast - I can get in and out (usually) pretty easily - great place for a breakfast meeting too!

COLD FOOD!!! I mean really?! Apparently breakfast at this place is way better than lunch or dinner. I've ordered catering from their west loop spot a few times and was very pleased. However, on a recent trip for lunch I was disappointed to say the least. My server was pleasant but the food was sub-par. My gravy had that "it's been sitting out film" and the potatoes were bland. And idk about anyone else, buy I so not appreciate giant pieces of corn husk in my fried corn. I will take MacAurthurs or any other place that claims to prepare southern food over this joint. The gumbo/cornbread were good and I may do takeout for that one day. However, I don't see myself returning there anytime soon.

There is a reason why, when my office wants to have a mini-celebration, we order lunch from Wishbone.  Thus far, not one of us has had a bad experience with the food, but rather the contrary.  Food is delicious and so comforting.  Literally, it's one of those moments where you take a bite and then you inhale deeply and think only the happiest thoughts.  The only thing that snaps my officemates and me out of our culinary reverie is the realization that there's only one cornbread muffin left. In which case, the happy workers luncheon becomes a bloody fight to the finish...  Just kidding!! Hah, but no. The cornbread really is that good and I'm not even usually a fan of cornbread. The reason I docked a star is for dinner portion sizes.  Having had such positive experiences with lunch takeout, I decided to treat the bf here to dinner.  I was surprised to find that the dinner portions were as small as the lunch portions. I ordered crab cakes and that was ok, but the bf ordered jambalaya. Looking at his plate, both he and I were kinda left scratching our heads thinking "wait, is that seriously it?"  Oh well.  Good thing there were cornbread muffins. I'm surprised to read about lack of quality service in other people's reviews.  Granted, again, my experience is mostly based on phone orders and food pick ups, but our server for one dinner was very southern friendly. AND she gave us extra cornbread muffins! So all in all, two thumbs up for Wishbone! Comfort food done very, very well.  ..Oh wait, did I mention the cornbread muffins?

of course I'm a Fan! What would I do about this place ? The staff is always friendly, They leave you alone if it doesn't appear that you need anything and the food is always good and Quick. The prices are Reasonable and I love their menu for Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner.

I love this place. I'm from Chicago and I rarely get to go back and experience real restaurants there. I'm still stuck on my local favorites like Harold's Chicken. Wishbone is awesome and cheap! It's comparable to NYC brunch spots. Can't wait to go back!

Coming from the Carolinas, I've been looking for a decent place for southern food in Chicago. Wishbone isn't quite like mama made it but is a solid alternative here in the city. The shrimp 'n grits is a must try.

I always order the same thing.  Make that thingsss.  I get the Southern Benedict and crunchy french toast.  The Southern Benedict is a bowl with  biscuits in the bottom with sausage gravy all over them and scrambled eggs on top.  The crunchy french toast is super soft french toast coated in crushed cornflakes.  It sounds unnecessary and it is unnecessary but I just can't help it.  I want the savory stuff and the sweet stuff so I get both.  A couple of times, I made the mistake of planning to go to work afterwards.  I failed and I felt bad about it.  Now, I plan on going home to nap afterwards and I succeed and so I feel good about it.

I wasn't sure whether or not to give this place 3 or 4 stars, but I ultimately decided on 4-stars because the food here is solid in taste. I order the veggie platter (mac n' cheese, sautéed spinach, and mashed p). It was pretty darn tasty and if you like lemon, you will love the spinach. The only thing missing were probably some pine nuts to make the dish perfect! My mother had the buttermilk fried chicken, red beans & rice, and the mac n' cheese. I was sure to try the food on her plate, it was all very good. Not to mention the little corn muffins they offer as an appetizer while you wait is pretty darn good too. I took a star off for laziness in service and decor. The service here is very low-beat. You definitely don't feel special and you get the cold shoulder...almost a "take it or leave it" vibe. My server was weird. Didn't card me for liquor (that should be a plus??) and rarely checked in with us. I think he was on the fritz after I told him I wasn't 21. Bad joke, hahaha, I know, but he was scared, then I fessed up. Gosh, that almost sounds cruel in writing.  The decor is nasty. I see why the lights are dim...so you don't see all the dirt, outdated furniture, and the missing bits. I can see if they were going for a broken in, "this is just like home" feel. However, if the booth's back space is splattered with old dried food particle, the seats are cracked/worn and someone else's butt prints remain for the taking...it's definitely time to update! All in all. I will be back and pray that the lights stay dim...because who knows whats lurking in the shadows!

MMMMM....I went twice in one week! Chicago has such a variety of food choices, but it's hard to find a good soul food restaurant. I liked that they stick to a specialty and didn't have a 6 page menu but proved that they could do one thing well: COMFORT FOOD! Wishbone isn't expensive and I appreciate the two sides included on entrees. It's not grandma's Sunday dinner...but it's close!

I have been having lunch at this Wishbone for 17 years. In the early days, I'd go there multiple times per week as there were no other options in the neighborhood back then. Great food. Great service.  The Berwyn Wishbone is good too. I have never been to the northern Wishbone, but the woman complaining that it's not kid friendly probably went to that one.

I have been here several times over the years.    We did arrive about 8pm, however this place seemed unusually deserted taking into account how crowded and lively it was in the past.  Is something up?  A restaurant concept that has run its course or in decline or maybe just a slow night... The jury is still in deliberations.  Stay tuned. It's a good thing we were not in a rush because the service was extremely slow as they were more concerned with closing down sections for their 10pm closing time than taking care of their customers at hand.  A big taboo to me is sweeping the floor with a broom, stirring up dust while customers in the same open section are dining.    The food, while it was good, it sure seemed a bit less exciting and lively than what I had encountered in the past.  Yes, it was good comfort food but something seemed to be missing.... It wasn't as tasty as in the past. Service is very slow and our waiter didn't bother to offer us another cup of coffee until we asked for more... and didn't inform us of desert options or ask us if we would like something else.   Poor service! The Wishbone of today deserves no higher than 3 stars in my opinion.

The strength for me lies in the breakfast/brunch items.  Normally when I come here I order a few things The Crunchy French Toast- Which is essentially deep fried french toast with syrup. Red Beans and Rice- Not bad, but lacks any super duper punch to it. Go for the hot sauce bottle....unfortunately. The Chicken Sausage- again...pretty standard. The cheese grits- delicious! A lil off in terms of flavor...but hey..their cheese grits and I'm okay with that. I remember the first time I had grits were in Georgia. Man....I miss those grits, but these grits were ok too. I normally eat everything above in one sitting. Sometimes I suffer from dunlap syndrome. My gut dunlap over my belt.  I would probably recommend that everyone try to place at least once for brunch, your opinions of the place will probably vary. Thanks!

My sister and I were driving through Chicago on the way home from a trip to see our dad in Iowa. We had our three children all under the age of four. She did some research and saw that the best place to take little ones downtown was wishbone.  There must be two wishbones in Chicago because this place was definitally not child friendly. In fact there was a sign at the front counter warning that kids weren't even allowed there after seven and crying would be monitored.   We had already paid fifteen dollars to park so we were commited to eating there.  They did have a very small childrens menu and the food was ok if you liked new Orleans type cuisine.  If you have small kids and are looking for a good place to stop for lunch do not believe the Chicago kids website because this is not it.  You would be much better off going to the rainforest cafe or rock and roll mcdonalds.

I've been to wish bone three time now and the service continues to get worse. The last time the waiter, in mid order, just walked off to talk to some other server and then came back several minutes later and just nodded for us to continue.

affordable southern food. use to eat here several years ago and would get the hopping john which i recall liking. just went for brunch on sat. got the black bean cakes which needed salt and seemed like something i could duplicate in my own kitchen easily.

WOW can not see how I waited this long to write a review. Some of the best southern food in Chicago. Always busy, be sure to come early on the weekends. I always have the biscuits and gravy. While not true southern style they are tasty!

This is one of my spots. Granted I don't go out for breakfast a lot, but the food is always good here. A girlfriend of mine woke me up this morning and invited me to breakfast so i said why not.  Our main goal for the meal was to go to a restaurant with a bar, this girl always wants to get a drink. Anyways, I've never been here on a weekday, but it was just as good! Not too crowded, just a steady sprinkle of guests. The hostess knew we wanted some mimosas so she decided to sit us by the bar, eventhough there was no bartender. We decided to opt for a table by the windows. ( I like to look outside, see the sun and imagine it's warm out.) anyways.  We ordered our drinks straight away and I eventually decided to go with the southern eggs Benedict. The entree arrived pretty quickly and I said,"what did I get myself into?" haha. Seriously, it's a huge bowl piled high with cornbread , eggs, Canadian bacon and thick, tasty sausage gravy. Yes, gravy with sausage in it! Every layer of this dish was a party in my mouth. Although I finished a third of it, it was so filling and hit the spot. On a side note, the grits were a bit undercooked. I like them light, buttery and fluffy. Today they had a little bit of snap to then. The server wasn't particularly spectacular in any way but she did her job. We tried to make her laugh, but she was a bit aloof and would just smile. We actually had more conversation with the ladies at the table next to us. She did go ahead and pack our leftovers for us, which is always appreciated.  You can never go wrong with Wishbone!

i went here on Sunday with my Family it was a cool place. we sat outside, it's mostly a breakfast place but they also do some lunch items / inside they have a big projection TV  where everyone was watching the bears game, last time i was there i had the crunch French  toast and the is really good, dogs are welcome on the patio. i go here because its by my brother but i would go out of my way to go here its thats good

So before I was to attend the Pretty City event at Flirty Girl Fitness, I figured I'd better eat something before I started to drink. As I walked down Washington, I remembered Wishbone being down the street. I always wanted to stop but never did. So onto Wishbone I go. It was 5 pm on a Wensenday and fairly empty. (I like empty, not a long wait) I asked if I could sit outside since it was nice and breezy. (They have a beautiful patio) I ordered the blackened catfish with fruit salad and collards greens with turkey meat. My food came extremely fast. I mean I blinked my eye and the next thing I know, my plate is in front of me. (might have something to do with the place being fairly empty)  I must say that I have no complaints about the food, service, setting or restaurant. The catfish was good, the greens were delish. (And I know greens, I cook them all the time) When you can eat collard greens without salt and their still good, you know what you're doing. I also very much enjoyed the fruit salad too.  For my meal, which included a lemon supreme dessert, I paid $16. All in all, it was a good experience at Wishbone and I will definitely be back.

We came wandering over here on a late Saturday morning hoping to avoid the crowds at Lou Mitchell's and Bongo Room.  Because it is a little further away, we were able to secure a table for our party of 13.   I had a hard time deciding what to order. I really wanted the cheesy grits with shrimp but i gave into the corncakes with real corn and green onion.  I also ordered a side of sauteed spinach with it, but it was not so sauteed and it left that feeling in my mouth that i always get with spinach.  the spicy bloody mary was fine. not as thick as i would like.   overall, a decent experience. not sure if it  stands out for me as a place i'd go to again and again.
Wishbone is a place where I have to just keep coming back because I have to try a million things on the menu. However, I always get the cheese grits because it reminds me of my lover, Mia L.

Utterly disappointed.  We went to Wishbone tonight because both my wife and I'd had a crappy week.  We wanted a bit of comfort food. Instead, we got cold-shoulder service from a waitress who didn't listen and then didn't care that we got the wrong order.  And then she didn't care to take the food back and couldn't be bothered get us the right dish.  Or even refill our drinks... or even actually say one word to that wasn't some sort of grunt...unless rolling her eyes counts.   Mistakes happen, it's okay, but treating us like crap from the start, that's not cool... The one star above the minimum is because the manager on duty really tried to make it right - and she was genuine and nice.

We had a beginning of the year MFA party here a few days ago. The space was nice and one of the toilets broken. We were served corn pancakes with red pepper sauce and some delectable corn muffins. Both were quite good. I liked the sauce. The main course, however, was meh. I was glad we could add accoutrements like chopped tomato, onion, and cheese to the beans and rice (because it would have been bland otherwise). The macaroni and cheese was also meh. Nothing you could do to dress that up. For the main dish, there was a choice of stuffed zucchini and catfish. As I'm a vegetarian, I chose the stuffed zucchini. It was pretty bland, but free food is free food, so I snarfed it anyway. The wine was okay. Not the greatest, but not the worst.  Would I return here for another meal? Probably only if we had another school function here...
So good! And they're building one in Beverly so we don't have to go to Oprahville anymore!

I brought my parents here on a rainy Saturday morning for breakfast since I haven't eaten at Wishbone since that really drunk St Patricks day a couple years ago.  From the little that I remembered, the black bean cakes were the best think I've ever consumed. We strolled in a 7:55am and saw one guy sitting outside reading the paper and drinking coffee and one guy inside doing the same.  I walked up to the hostess stand outside and she said, "We don't open until 8am." I looked at my watch for effect and then looked at the guy clearly sitting down already drinking coffee and then we backed up 5 steps, waited for 5 minutes and then walked back up.  At that point she directed us inside and we were still the first people in.  I don't know, it was weird.  I know it's outside so you can't "lock" any doors but still, we couldn't sit down and wait those 5 minutes inside with menus?  Whatevs. So once we did sit down, we all got coffee and holy mother was that good.  Strong and really hot but really good.  And thanks to the guy who was bored and walking around consistently with that pot I probably drank about 4 cups.  Yikes. So I had to get the black bean cakes obviously, my parents got french toast and an omelet I think.  They both said theirs were really good.  Mine, ugh mine were just not.  They were sooo dry, I just really wanted to save them.  I dumped my poached egg on top and the mango salsa and nothing could really salvage it.  I was bummed.  But full.  They give you a lot of potatoes, shoot.  So yeah, it wasn't a total failure but it wasn't the 5 star trip I was hoping for.  And I definitely wouldn't wait in that crazy summer Sunday morning line that forms.

I'd been to Wishbone for dinner before and not had great experiences, so I internally groaned a bit when my wife asked if we could walk up there for breakfast this morning, but externally, I cheerfully agreed.   It was busy when we got there, but there were four tables on the patio - in the sun - which we didn't mind, so we sat.  It got quite a bit busier about 10 minutes after we arrived so I'm glad we got there when we did! We shared the crunchy french toast and peach pancakes, eggs, fresh squeezed (delicious!) orange juice, and sausage links.  Our orders were taken promptly, juice and coffee came out fast - amazing considering how busy they were - and food just a few minutes later.  Everything was cooked to perfection except the eggs, which we ordered scrambled hard, but they came out a bit runny.  The crunchy French Toast was AWESOME... pancakes were excellent, but let's remember, they're pancakes - it's difficult to make them poorly. Server brought our bill out in a timely manner when we finished, and was prompt and friendly despite the fact that he was running around like a maniac with so many tables full.  My only complaints: 1) eggs runny 2) water glass not filled by bus staff at any point 3) latte comes in a drink glass... OW!... and was way too sweet 4) value - we paid kind of a lot for breakfast food - $20+ per person Still, these shortcomings were really not bad considering how busy they were and were easily offset by the rest of the meal.  A solid B+ of a dining experience.

My husband and I used Wishbone to cater our wedding reception, and they were outstanding. Reyna was in charge of our event, and she was great. She was incredibly helpful and organized. The staff was super polite, friendly, and helpful. Not only were they were totally on top of everything, but numerous guests commented on how nice they were. Our guests also raved about the food. Even though it buffet style, the food was hot and fresh as if it had just come out of the kitchen. The quality of the food did not suffer a bit. The food was also a hit with our vegetarian guests despite the fact that we had meat entrees - the sides we hearty and tasty enough to be a meal themselves.  The only negative encounter was with our original contact person, who was not good about getting back to me about anything. But that was not a problem once Reyna took over our event. I would definitely recommend Wishbone for their catering. They have a great selection to choose from, and their catering options are very flexible and affordable.

Quite possibly some of the worst service in the city.  We came here for a Sunday brunch and sat on the patio.  For the first 10 minutes there was not a waitress in sight (mind you this means not even water on a 90+ degree day, sitting in the sun).  She finally moseyed on over and took our order and when she returned with our water and coffee I asked that she replace the cream and butter (which was now oil) to which her reply was "that's just how we do it" and only took the cream to replace.  I guess we were supposed to spread the "oil" on our pancakes and toast later. We sat there for quite a bit longer while we saw the people next to us that were seated about 15 minutes later than we were get their food and start eating.  She finally notices that something is off and goes to ask.   Food was decent.  Pancakes were good, potatoes were incredibly salty. All in all, nothing is worth sitting through the horrendous service again.

Wishbone is one of my favorite brunch spots.  I have never ordered anything but breakfast items. The breakfast potatoes are divine.  I'm not a grits fan, but my friends always order the cheese grits, so they must be good.   In addition to their consistently great brunch, they have a full bar with great specialty drinks. Overall, a great brunch spot!

I kind of loved this place!  I mean, first off, I love southern food, and there's not that many places in Chicago that even make it, not to mention make it well.  But Wishbone is a winner. First you get to pick between cheesy cornbread muffin things and something else (not sure who picks something else, cornbread is never ever the wrong answer to a question).  For my entree I got the bowl of chili, which is different than most chili's.  It's served over a bed of rice, and all very thick.  I ate it with a fork!  But it's fantastic and meaty and saucy and mmm.  I also tried my fellow diners' shrimp and grits and sweet potato side dish, both phenom. It's one of those places with a small to normal sized menu, yet you found at least 10 things you want to try.  Love that.  Also, bonus, great outdoor seating area.  And, although not my thing, one of my dinner-mates was very pumped to discover all-day breakfast service!  Can't wait to go back!

Wishbone is consistently good. I go there twice a month and am always satisfied. They are always welcoming and go out of their way to make it comfortable for kids! The service is fast and friendly and the food is interesting and tasty. It's not exactly a place you write home about, but here I am writing about it.  I recommend the grits and the different lemonades. Yummy!

Wishbone is the definition of 3 stars. It's never amazing and it's never bad.  Considering it's Southern cooking, I've always been disappointed by their Jambalaya but everything else is good enough.  Best thing about the place is the early bird breakfast special (pre-9am)(available for take-out as well). 2 eggs, bacon/sausage, potatoes/grits, bread/muffin for $4.85. Can't beat that anywhere.  This place is always jammed on weekends for brunch and I wouldn't ever wait to eat here - but considering its close proximity to my home and office, it's great for that early breakfast special and/or a quick lunch.  Good, good, and good.

If you're tired of the same old same old eggs benedict-omelette-pancakes routine, try some soul-food. The place is huge. We had to wait (once). But there is an indoor waiting area so you are not subjected to the cold winds in the winter.  The staff is really friendly and would give you recs on what's good on the menu. I like the flavors of southern food, so much oomph. The red beans and rice is my favorite so far. I did not expect to be inclined to eat beans and rice for breakfast, but this is amazing. Its traditional New Orleans rice with Chicken Andouille sausage. NOM. I've also had the Jambalaya omelette, which is tasty but I don't think jambalaya goes well with eggs. too soggy. Dying to try dinner/lunch menu here.  Also a note: I'm one of those people who don't eat pork and sometimes it is hard to find rice and beans or sausage that does not contain pork. Whilst they still have a lot of pork in their menu, Wishbone certainly have plenty of options for the non-porcine eater.

I love Wishbone for breakfast/lunch - Their biscuits and gravy are the best I've ever had - Great cornbread and potatoes! Service is excellent and because of the size of the place you're usually not waiting long or if at all.

This place was ok. I don't think it was as great as everyone exclaims about. They're described as soul-food or southern-food, maybe that's why my pancakes and eggs had a certain taste to them. I was thinking maybe organic. It wasn't bad, just different. Went here for mother's day, definitely reasonably priced! I'd go back just to try other things.

I love this place. The staff is always so friendly and they always recommend something new. I love the shrimp and cheese grits. i always have a good time there and enjoy the food. If you want great food and friendly staff, have dinner here... :)

If you like soul-food, Wishbone is the place to be. Went there Saturday night, the beef brisket with BBQ sauce was amazing. I'm big into service, and Wishbone always delivers! Brunch at wishbone is also great....gotta have the grits.  Live, Love, Eat.  JLR

Mmmm...chicken fried steak. My boyfriend I I went here for dinner early on a Friday night - it was very pleasant. He claims that breakfast borders on phenomenal, so I'm excited to try that. We got the chicken fried steak and the Jambalaya. The chicken fried steak was AMAZING - not deep fried, like i expected, but pan fried, with gravy that was so good I almost ate it with a spoon when I was done. The Jambalaya was also excellent - not quite spicy enough, but once the really good hot sauce on the table was added, up there with any jambalaya I've had, even in New Orleans.The corn muffins, aforementioned excellent hot sauce, and a slice of chocolate pecan pie with wonderful whip cream definitely completed the meal. Service wasn't the best I've ever had, but did what it needed to do.

My Dad had just flown in from Dubai to visit me in Chicago for a couple of days, and my mission was to treat him to a filling and memorable Brunch.  We had a long walk to this restaurant from the Blue Line, and by the time we got there we were starving and exhausted. We were seated outside on their roofed patio where we enjoyed our drinks.  When the food finally came I was in awe.  I had an unforgettable shrimp omelette with a side of black beans and a homemade biscuit.  If you're looking for a southern style breakfast that's very satisfying, Wishbone is for you.

I had such high expectations for Wishbone, unfortunately it was a lack-luster experience.  The service was friendly as we were always approached with a smile, but that wasn't enough to award them more stars.    I think we visited this place on an off-day because we weren't impressed.  I ordered the Corn Cakes.  Corn cakes are similar to pancakes but made with cornmeal, diced onions and corn.  Mine were ok, but something was lacking.   A ramekin of sauce came on the side  - not sure what kind of sauce it was.  I think it was supposed to be a spicy southwest sauce?  not sure.  I couldn't really taste anything.   My friend ordered the egg & pepper sandwich, and although she didn't like it, she inhaled it due to being so hungry.   I'm not sure if the kitchen was having an off-day, but it wasn't my favorite meal.   I know I will visit again because I have such high hopes. I will even order the Corn Cakes again.  The menu is interesting and the servers are friendly.  Perhaps a Monday morning breakfast is not the best time to dine there.   I'll be back.

WIshbone is a good old standby for me for solid, comfort food.  During the day, there is a steady flow of diners, and the wait for brunch on weekends could be trying.  So my secret, come for dinner.  When the southern comfort craving hits, Wishbone is the place for me.  Buttery cornbread comes in 2 tiny mini muffin-size morsels.  Just enough to whet the appetite.  My latest dinner, i had the fried chicken wings appetizer.  Crunchy crunchy breading, seriously giving Popeye stiff competition.  For entree i had a special of whole sauteed rainbow trout.  The whole fish is butterflied, lightly breaded and sauteed meuniere style.  Tender moist flesh.  Bits of walnuts gave it textural crunch.  As with most of their entrees, you choose 2 sides.  For tonight, i had collard greens and black eyed peas & rice.  Tender braised collared greens with huge chunks of turkey meat.  The black eyed peas & rice provided a good counterpoint to the richness of the greens and the trout.  Wash it all down with glasses of Goose Island Matilda.  Ah, what a way to spend a quiet, low-key Saturday night.

After showing a listing in the West Loop we decided to corral our hunger with a quick stop at Wish Bone. It had been a while since we had crossed paths with this Chicago standby and our revisit was well beyond satisfactory. Choosing from the lunch menu I opted for pulled pork with red beans and rice and vegetable pasta salad. My wife chose a salmon dish and the boys had chicken fingers from the kid's menu. Washed down with sweet tea the meal drove it straight and long proving to be as satisfying as it was filling. Glad to reacquaint with an old standby that still manages to pull in one of the city's most diverse clientele. Keep up the good work.

I enjoy Wishbone but it does not merit 4 stars.  I like the ideas of paintings with cows and chickens and I like the idea of cajun food.  However, I am not positive I am crazy about the way Wishbone merges the two concepts. Honestly, for the money Wishbone is a decent place to check out.  I have never left there feeling unsatisfied but I have also never fallen off my chair eating there.  All in all, if you are looking for a "solid but not great" place, this is the place for you.   They do have some good Goose Island on tap.

I like Wishbone, but if I had a choice of any breakfast place in Chicago (and you magically didn't have to wait in line), I would not choose Wishbone however,  It's southern creole breakfast, which makes it different. Like shrimp and cheese grits, which I know gave two of my friends horrible stomach aches, but it tasted really good. The crab cake egg benedicts are really good (hollandaise on the side of course). They did mess up my eggs though one time ... they completely overcooked them.  Their pancakes here are awesome, pay the extra 2 bucks for the syrup, you won't be disappointed.  I ordered the Red Eggs, which tasted okay, needed a little more seasoning, it was kind of bland.  Service was great though when my party of 10 was finally able to sit down considering how packed it was.  I feel like it's a hit or miss with this restaurant. I can have incredible food one day, but then sub par the next time I visit.

Solid Southern comfort food in a fun and backyard bbq setting. Showed up for brunch on a packed Sunday morning with a line out the door, but we waited only 10 minutes.  Our waitress was as sweet as can be and happily let us linger over our coffee and chat, long after we had finished.  Here's what we had: - Salmon cakes with grits:  came with eggs, corn muffin, and hollandaise.  Had cheese added to the grits b/c that's the only way grits should be eaten. Muffin was flecked with corn kernels, tiny, but good. - Corned beef hash with potatoes:  came with eggs and a biscuit, which was airy and more like a dinner roll than that at Popeye's (which is perhaps the best biscuit on earth) - Hot chocolate:  watery and the milk had been scalded, as a sticky film had congealed on top. Portions were on the small size, and food could have been better but the ambiance and service were great.  Perfect example of food not being the only criteria, aside from decor and service, in a complete dining experience.  Southern comfort is hard to turn down.

Solid food. Come here on a weekend and be ready for a wait. But remember, it's worth the wait because... its wishbone!  Yummy. (Here's an insiders trick... Shhhhh..... Keep it quiet......   Order the food "For Pickup" and avoid the lines and get the food fast!"). Wishbone has clearly established itself as a main-stay in Chicago.  From quality Southern-style breakfast cooking to the slightly eccentric Vegetarian food options (that I've heard rock your socks - Black Bean Patties).  The Spinach omelete is wonderful.  Order with the hashbrowns and I'm sure you'll be sending me a Yelp compliment right afterwards. heh heh. Remember,  arrive early,  or call ahead and pick it up to bring back home (or to the park once the warm weather arrives!). Cheers!
Hooray for North Carolina-style pork BBQ with a real vinegar based sauce, so rare here in Chicago.  Sides were good and it was a reasonable value.

This place has amazing pancakes! I ordered a side of pancakes with my brunch and I'm glad I did, it was kind of crunchy at the sides and was firm yet fluffy if that makes any sense.  Other than that the coffee was also good, the breakfast and lunch menus were okay, One time I had their meatloaf which was excellent and my friend had the crabcakes, just okay.  The cornbread was more like cake, I prefer cornmeal texture in my cornbread.  One of my friends also had cheesey grits that were just okay, good to taste but after too much it was just overwhelming.   The waitress was super nice, kind of like "southern hospitality."  The atmosphere is open feeling and there's normally lots of tables including a nice bar to eat or drink at.  This place can get pretty busy during brunch so expect a little delay in the waiters service, but they are doing the best they can.

I have been missin my shrimp and grits on Sunday mornings. And that fye ass Peach mimosa and pecan pie. I'm drooling at the thought.... But my bf ordered the biscuits w/sausage gravy and got the worst case of food poisoning I have ever seen. I tried to alert management of the problem who avoided me like the repo man. I was only trying to make sure no one else got sick. Honestly I still love you guys, so does my bf, he's actually ready for more, so am I.

Soo many on-line reviews have recommended this place that I knew I had to try it while vacationing in Chicago. I DEFINITELY could have passed. Ambiance= poor Service= average polite Food= below average I ordered the crab cakes and shared an order of Banana Pancakes. I must admit the pancakes were top notch, I would come back for those but the rest not so much. The home fries are over sized potatoes dried out, my eggs were definitely FAKE! They reminded me of the powdered eggs I ate @ camp as kid. My mango smoothie was more like Mango puree the texture was off. I def could live w.o this place. I would recommend you pass.

Went there this Sunday morning for brunch/breakfast at 10:30 AM as part of a party of 3. Seated immediately and ordered the North Carolina Crab Cakes(since that is where I hail from) with poached eggs, cheese grits, and a corn muffin.  Everything hit the mark with the crab cakes nicely spicy.  Definitely would go again.

Eh, this place is okay..... This is Chicago.  The brunch capital of the world.  If you really want to compete in this high caliber arena then you have to turn out some amazing breakfast foods.   At Wishbone I ordered my ole' standby: spinach and tomato egg-white omelette.  What I received was the tiniest little egg thingy I've ever seen.  I could have eaten it in maybe 2 bites.  Even my friend remarked at how small my omelette was.  And it accompanied no spinach, or tomato.  I have no problem if Wishbone operated like a diner, but they don't.  And their prices need to ilicit a better product. The service at Wishbone was great....very relaxed and friendly.  The menu is rather large and you can definitely find whatever you are looking for!  Wishbone isn't bad, per se, it's just not one of those cute, type-A, voted most popular in the yearbook brunch hot spots.  I just like those better....and their omelettes.

After connecting with an old friend, we decided to grab a nice brunch to catch up. After reading many reviews, I decided that this would be the best place to get a nice, filling, good old fashioned southern breakfast (Just like grandma use to make!). I ordered the wishbone omlette with cheese grits and my counterpart had the fried catfish and grits.  My eggs were a little dry but the cheese grits were DELISH! My friend allowed me one bite of his catfish and I wish I had ordered that instead. Very moist and well seasoned.  I didn't think this place had the greatest food I've ever eaten (based on my overcooked eggs and the hard muffin that came with my meal). Nor did they have the best service (our waitress was very eclectic and a little awkward at times as she stood over our table in silence for 5 minutes while we got our money together for the bill...ummm...have we been here that long or are you rushing to get us out of here because you have somewhere else to be?) Not to mention they moved us out of our quaint booth because a larger group was coming in. (however they made up for that with free dessert which was very tasty!)  I wouldn't say it was the worst, I'll just say it is "AIGHT". As long as you don't get the eggs and there isn't a big crowd, you'll be satisfied.

Yum!  I've been here for dinner before, and it was good but just okay.  Brunch was SO good.  I had the crunchy french toast and sausage.  Outstanding.  I tried some of my friend's cheese grits too - also delicious.  Will definitely try the Shrimp and Grits next time.  Love it.

Wishbone is #2 in my West Loop breakfast cycle.  There's a ton of seating and even though there's usually a wait-- it never lasts long.  I would say the majority of the menu is worth ordering and that's always a benefit at breakfast.  They also serve liquor, which cannot be said for their counterparts in the West Loop breakfast game. I'm a HUGE fan of the breakfast potatoes-- perfectly fried w/ soft rings of onions.. for my tastes, no one does them better.  The egg dishes are great, the shrimp and grits and crunchy french toast also can't be missed. Unfortunately, the service is below average more often then not, but the experience as a whole is always pleasant.  You can ensure that with a bloody mary! (If you couldn't tell from my blatant dropping of the word "breakfast"-- that's as far as my recommendation goes.  I tried dinner once.  NO good.)

I came here on a Friday afternoon after a meeting. It was crowded but not to the point where we had to wait for seating. I ordered the chicken and biscuits along with a side of macaroni, which was one of the lunch specials. My bill came out to be about $13 with lemonade. Overall, the service was excellent but food wasn't very tasty to me. I don't know, maybe it was what I ordered that didn't have much flavor to it.
Good food, good service, the drinks were okay...but it lacked something..portion size was acceptable.  I'd go again if in the area.

I have to stop here every time I come to the CHI ! So far I always order the same thing which is Salmon Cakes with Greens and Sweet Potatoes (it automatically comes with cole slaw). They have numerous sides to choose from. I have tried three of their alcoholic beverages and they are de-li-cious.

Last week was the first time I had been to this location.  Normally I go to the one on Lincoln, and yes, it's typically for brunch.  I've eaten there once for dinner and my friends like to order food from there for their parties.   Came here with the bf and there were 2-3 ladies just standing around, but no one around to seat.  Keep in mind, this is about 10am on a Monday.  I look, no one.  After the lady at the register finishes ringing something up, she looks at me with a huge smile and asks how many.  I like her.  As she's about to seat us she tells some ladies just standing around (out of sight from the entrance) that she was saying there were people there.  "Oh, I just saw some lady there on the phone".........."Yeah, because there was a lady on the phone.  However, there were more people, and there's more behind them."  The lady who sat us was really friendly, upbeat and apologetic.  Order my bloody mary.  It wasn't bad, but I've had better.  The crunchy french toast didn't taste right at first, and since I don't use syrup, I wasn't sure if I was going to like it this time. After a few bites it tasted alright.  The chicken sausage for $3 was a single link sliced in half.  Whatever, it was good.  The boy had eggs and they looked gross, but then again, most restaurant eggs do.  His potatoes were delicious.  Better than usual.   I want to like this location, but I think I'll stick to the one on Lincoln.

Since there are so many great places to brunch in Chicago, my hubby and I try to make it a policy to not go to the same restaurant more than twice.  Wishbone is the *exception* for brunch - AND we take all our out of town guests here since we live so close.   We have almost eaten the entire special breakfast list and the Shrimp and Grits is still the alltime fave.   Don't forget about the drinks too!  I don't like bloody mary's but my hubby and numerous guests love them.  I personally love the freshly squeezed Carrot/Beet/Ginger juice.  (Have you ever seen such a beautiful and healthy neon pink drink before?) Another note on the drinks - during the *summer*, the watermelon lemonade is the most GLORIOUS refreshing drink you must try.  (Just as refreshing as Mario's Italian lemonade, if not more.)

My boyfriend and I finally came here after hearing how good it was. It was just okay. For brunch, I expect to wait - especially when there are bloody mary's and mimosas being offered.   That's fine.  What I absolutely hated is that the hostess told everyone (parties of two, parties of twelve) that the wait was 10-15 minutes.  When I saw the line waiting, I was skeptical, but since I had never been there thought that they knew best.  After standing around for thirty minutes (and hearing the hostess tell everyone 10-15 minutes), we were seated.     At this point, I knew that it could get no more than 3.5 stars. The service was okay - our waiter was probably over seated and was rushing.  He never really came back to make sure what we wanted - only got his attention by approaching the kitchen for ketchup. The place was jam-packed and I am not sure why.  To me, the wait was not worth it.  We sat right by the kitchen - that should mean we get super hot food right? No.     I am always comparing the Eggs Benedicts since that is what I order 90% of the time.  Here the eggs were only lukewarm.  Down 1/2 a star. The hollandaise sauce was minimal and nothing special.  The Egnlish muffin was burnt and I was "fighting it" just to cut it.  The potatoes were quite good.  I will say that it was real reasonably priced.  Yet, something was just missing.  I would give this 2.5 stars if I could give the half.  3 just seemed too high since I was so pissed off with the seating situation.  Would I come back? Sure.  Would I wait? No, and I wouldn't believe that there was a "ten" minute wait.

I visited Wishbone on New Year's Day with a group of friends who had a taste for Southern goodness.  Being that my family all migrated here from the south, I usually have pretty high expectations when it comes to "soul food". However, I realize that the great southern restaurants are not found in posh urban neighborhoods.  That being said, my expectations were met at Wishbone.  I ordered the Shrimp and Grits (as did many of my friends) and my hubs ordered the Pan fried Catfish.  I was thoroughly satisfied with my food, and the hubs was with his.  For a quick "southern, soulfood" kick, Wishbone is a nice place to visit.  I will be back.

It's ok nothing special. Ordered breakfast burrito, it's mostly black beans, didn't even taste salsa and the eggs. My gf had shrimp omlette, it was decent, and so where the home fries. The bloody Mary comes in a big glass but tasted like water mixed with tomato paste. It wasn't so bad to give it 2 stars but it's just not quite a 3 stars.

I personally do not like this place. I came there with my family and it took nearly 2 hours to get our food. I ordered  "thunder chicken nuggets and fries" for my 2 year old thinking that was safe, however, it turned out to be chicken breast sliced in little strips and roasted potatoes. My daughter was not happy at all with that, and I ended up making her dinner when we got home. I ordered the crab cakes which were just ok. They were too soggy in my opinion. We had to go to the bar to get our own silverware and even ask for refills on water. They put 8 people at a table setting for 6. We were very cramped! I won't be back.

Chicago sure has a lot of brunch spots and I wasn't disappointed by Wishbone, but just didn't have that much of a memorable experience to warrant anything, but 3 stars. To my waitresses recommendation I got the shrimp & grits, which she said was the most popular dish there. It came out and wasn't much to look at, but was surprisingly good for someone who normally doesn't eat grits. Everything else was pretty standard so going to have to cut this review a bit short.

Brunch, 12pm on a Saturday. I ordered the crab cakes, two eggs over medium, a biscuit and cheese grits. You see, I have this issue -- I like my food HOT. I am not talking burn my tongue off and make me cry hot, but you know, not luke warm and everything (even my eggs) was luke warm or cold. The sausage gravy was bland and so was everything else. Then to top it all off, my mimosa tasted rancid and my coffee was only filled once.  Once, in 45 minutes.   I am sure that at times that breakfast here is superb but it was NOT on the Saturday I went.  It was a total waste of money. I'll stick with my own eggs at home.

I like Southern food, and I so wanted to like this place, but nope. The fish cakes were very bad (they tasted like fish heated in a microwave 5 days after having been cooked...), the eggs were OK, but nothing great. The grit was barely passable.  No, I don't think I am going back there any time soon.

Stumbled in this place with my girlfriend after seeing some sketch comedy in the area. The place was pretty empty around 9pm but we went in anyway. I'm so glad I did.  The deep fried green beans were to die for. The burger my girlfriend had was great she said (I don't eat beef) and I gobbled down the rainbow trout I had. The little plate of rolls and cornbread they give you was awesome too and we asked for seconds. They have some very cool art around, with wooden chickens and various food/animal life.  All in all very cool place, will definitely go again when in the area.

Every single review seems to be for brunch, so I'll break the mold. We had lunch. On a weekday! Because we were out on site and there is remarkably little choice around if you want to sit down. So - this is an expense-lunch review which I will try not to colour with the fact I didn't have to pay. I'm quite good with these sort of things because I still check the prices as it's not really good form to order the most expensive thing on the menu, washed down with 17 drinks. In my mind, anyway.  I actually ate here twice, and I really enjoyed it both times. Very fast service which was friendly and helpful. The food was fantastic - yes, it's southern so i wasn't expecting anything endorsed by the heart foundation, but i did actually have a salad and it was equal to my crawfish cakes in joyousness.  Corn muffins - amazing. Sauteed spinach - amazing. Sweet potato with nuts - amazing. Brisket got the thumbs up from a fellow diner. I'd go back just for the spinach, and my other fellow diner spent half the time trying to coax the recipe for the tahini dressing out of our server. Good stuff. Right portion sizes too.

Cheese grits, cornbread with butter and honey, and salmon cakes with hollandaise sauce - if any of this sounds appetizing to you, then you're in the right place.   Otherwise, the dishes seem half-hearted (one crayon short of a full box of flavor) and the portions are a bit skimpy.  I want to love this place, but would only choose Wishbone over Le Peep across the street because of its outdoor seating.

1 Star for seating us immediately on a Sunday around 10 am. 1 Star for having delicious grits & biscuits and gravy (My southern roots were well-fed here) 1 Star for speedy service (although I never saw our server after we placed our order, I did have everything I needed) 1 Star for the warm, happy feeling I had when I left There are lots of brunch places still to be tried, but I would have no hesitation to return to Wishbone!
I like this place. I have been there a few times! I love their grits.. and their salmon cakes!!! I need to go back here!! the wait is not very long either like some other breakfast places.
Fantastic bloody mary!!!! I also had the shrimp Omelette and was surprised at how good it was! Staff was friendly and helpful

Considering this place has 199 reviews already, mine almost seems pointless. BUT, it's not! Ohhh Wishbone. Was supposed to be meeting place of the 1st meetup w/ the BF. That night never happened and somehow, months later and I had still yet to visit Wishbone.  We scheduled a Saturday brunch date for there in July---but work beckoned him, so that fell through, too. :( (anyhow, I digress). It seemed Wishbone was just not in the cards for me. That all changed a few weeks ago. Boy was I mad that I'd waited that long to go. I LOVED IT. For starters, it was a Saturday during brunch hours when I went. My friend and I didn't wait for very long. We got outdoor seating. The service was great. Weather was great. And my grits were DE.LISH!  I AM A G.R.I.T (s)  (Girl Raised In the South), so I'm picky about my grits. Man, those grits were better than the ones I make at home.  Bellinis? Delightful. About 3 drinks in, I had to stop myself from keeping them coming.  I leave a star off, because my 2nd time at Wishbone wasn't so delightful. I took my mom there on her recent visit. We sat inside. Dark and dreary inside. Service was EXTREMELY poor (We had to ASK for water! and it wasn't even that busy.) My shrimp and grits were just ok (I think the gravy that they put on it is a bit off.)  Overall, I would DEF go back to Wishbone for the grits and drinks!  To date--it is my favorite brunch spot in Chi.

I love coming to Wishbone on a lazy Saturday or Sunday. It's always packed and there's always a line, but I don't mind waiting. The restaurant is fashioned like a big-ole cafeteria. It's the kind of restaurant that you're asked to take things up a notch because if you don't, you'll drown in the sounds of your neighbors voices.  In terms of service - quick and speedy, but sometimes forgetful. I've had to repeatedly ask for lemons for my water or a refill on coffee or tea - but I don't have any complaints. This is not a fine dining restaurant. The servers cover many more tables at any one given time than servers fancier restaurants. They don't have time to dilly daddle and spoon feed you. For food, all I have to say is shrimp and grits. YES. Oh, and the biscuits and gravy is so worth the extra 5 miles you have to run at the gym later that day. They also have a great weekday early bird special - for $3.99 you get two eggs, two bacon or sausage, and two pancakes. I've been a few time when I've had friends in town leaving on an early morning flight. We'd grab a quick bite at the bar then head to O'hare. Perfect!

There are certain things about "breakfast" that I consider weaknesses -- Bloody Mary's and biscuits and gravy. I think Wishbone knows me. Seriously. I know Southern breakfast is sort of an acquired taste, but if you haven't acquired it, you probably suck and are seriously missing out on life. Cheese grits... mmm... cajun omelets... I could go on and on. Wishbone is cute bustling, and a good place to cure a Sunday morning hangover.

Wishbone is an occasional diversion for us.  Some dishes here are interesting on creativity, while below-average on taste.  Kudos to the crunchy french toast, but you must ask for REAL maple syrup or you will get stuck with that cheap SAV-A-Lot stuff.  Blackened catfish is terrible, just TERRIBLE and tastes so fishy you may puke.  Went here Tuesday night and was quite disappointed in this dish, not to mention the collards, which were so limp they looked like dried up seaweed.   The corn muffins are a nice appetizer, but can't help the stock value of this restaurant.   Having roots in the south, I enjoy a good southern meal, Wishbone just doesn't deliver.   Oh yeah, the food arrives so quick you can't help but wonder if it's pre-plated.  The beans & rice dishes look like they''ve been sitting for a while.  No doubt, we've gone here for the last time.

Another delicious start to my morning!   For those who need a 'hare the dog', note that on Sunday's, they can't serve you alcohol until 10:30am. So be patient! If you show up by 10am, there is almost no wait.  Any later, then you'll be piling up outside the door to get a seat. For some odd reason, I get a craving for shrimp everytime to go. It could be that I can't think of any other restaurant that serves shrimp for breakfast?  If you like shrimp - choose either the Savannah Omelette or the Shrimp and Grits - big succulent pieces of shrimp cooked perfectly! Really nice bloody Mary's and decent service.

YES I HAVE BEEN BACK ALREADY...GEEZ I like to eat :P Well this time I went for lunch and NOOOO complaints. We sat outside and was wated on accordingly. I ordered the smoothered porkchop and collards/mac and cheese.... Okay the only tip I have on the dish is don't expect the porkchop to be filling unless you on a diet...they have TWO as an option listed on the menu for a reason....the reason is simple ONE won't fill you up even with sides. Overall I suggest you simply go and enjoy!@

After going there every weekend for a month straight, i thought i had discovered breakfast bliss. But on the 5th visit, i was thrown off my high horse... I discovered the breakfast sandwich (eggs,cheese, i dont get it with the spinach though) on two small, buttery, deliciously amazing croissants. I ordered that for 4 weeks straight, but as i looked over the menu before our waitress got to our table, i couldn't find my beloved, buttery breakfast sandwich. Panic ensued, as i asked her about them. She told me they were taken off the menu. I wanted to cry. Ok, not really, but that was enough to deter us from going there the next saturday morning. I ordered eggs with cheese and toast, and made my own breakfast sandwich. Albeit it wasn't as incredibly delicious as if they were on those buttery croissants of heaven. All it takes for you to make those is the croissants, you already have everything else! Please?!  I'll definitely be back anyway since my bf has developed a sad, sad, addiction to the shrimp and grits and me to the crunchy french toast.  WHY WISHBONE, WHY?

This is a great place for a casual brunch. Me and my husband stumbled upon this place while wandering around and boy were we lucky! Their orange juice is freshly squeezed in-house, service was quick and the prices are super affordable. I had a fruit pancake that was everything a pancake should be, light, fluffy, with a slight savoriness. Excellent. My husband had the southwest breakfast burrito, we're from AZ and he said it tasted better than the burritos back home.  Sunday's are busy in the morning, but the staff seems to keep up pretty well with the rush. We'll definitely be stopping by again.
One of the best breakfast spots. So many robust flavors and spices. I forget what I order there...some kind of chicken sausage with scrambled eggs or something. I heart this place.

Liked it [Nick Swarsden style voice...] We've been going to the Wishbone by Lincoln and Belment for a few years, so I had low expectations for the original location.  Boy was I wrong (and jaded and pessimistic and a downer and...). It was significantly better than the Lincoln location.  Even though the milling masse of West Loopers and black bikers (in starched jeans) gave me pause, the line moved fast at 11:00AM.  How fast?  Ten minutes was all we waited. Wife has the chocolate chip pancakes and seemed pretty happy.  I had a bacon omelet with a side biscuit and gravy.  OMG, the gravy was actually edible, and how do you say... Good!  The gravy had noticeable chunks of sausage (nice), and had that ever so slightly salty taste that gravy should have, not that tastes-like-flour-looks-like-gravy flavor that I run into all too often. Service was perfect, though we had to wait a bit for our food.  But the joint was so busy I am not surprised. Would definitely go again.

This remains a reliable brunch option for me, particularly when I'm in the West Loop, but I will never get why some people claim this as their "favorite brunch" spot in the city. Really? While the southern twists on favorites is nice, I'm never all that impressed with what they do with eggs benedicts or black beans or salmon. Rather, it's the simple dishes--the Yankee eggs, the fruit presentation, tasty oatmeal--that keep me satisified. I dunno, I'm not the brunch aficionado that so many yelpers are.  Maybe there's something specific that I just have to try?

Dear Wishbone, Thank you for soothing my massive hangover. Your scrambled eggs and peppers really made my day and I'm pretty sure your fruit salad was the only reason my head stopped spinning. Because of you, I was able to remove my sunglasses by 4:00.  I am forever grateful. Your girl,  C

I heart Wishbone!  I've been twice this month, and both times the food was very tasty and the service was spot on.  Especially the last time, I noticed that all the servers were in a particularly good mood.  The cornbread starters takes me back to my mom's kitchen.  I am a fan of the salmon, sweet potatoes with nuts, and black beans.  I also highly enjoyed their strawberry lemonade!  For both meals, the portions were just right - I was full and my plate was empty. The food isn't anything incredibly innovative - it's just done well without most of the usual guilt of grease or fat.  The decor is also fun and casual.  I love people watching on a lazy summer afternoon, and Wishbone provides the goods.

Did you ever think your food was good because it seemed like it was supposed to be good?  That's this place.  Everything leading up to the actual grub was excellent.  Cool atmosphere, got seated quickly even on a busy Sunday lunchtime, very addicting watermelon lemonade and carrot juice (had to get seconds), great service.  Prices are reasonable.  We were very impressed. And then the food arrived.  No way to sugarcoat it -- the black bean cakes are gross.  The mango salsa isn't enough to turn this bland pile of dryness around.  The jambalaya omelette was a little better, with the excellent stewed chicken and sausage almost making up for the completely plain-tasting eggs.  Flavored Egg Beaters from the supermarket would have been better.  The cheesy grits were definitely the highlight of the meal -- I could have chugged bowls of that stuff.  Cornbread and potatoes were also above average.  The sides far outshone the entrees. Who knows, maybe we ordered the wrong stuff?  I'm a big fan of Southern food, but what I ate at Wishbone wasn't it.  I might have to go back though and get some more cheesy grits...

I just got back from a delicious brunch with my wife at Wishbone. There were a lot of people who seemed like they were waiting for a table outside, but when we walked up to the hostess we were able to get in without waiting. She had an andouille sausage omelette with potatoes and a cornbread muffin, all of which were great. I had the corn cakes with sausage patties and eggs. The eggs may have been a touch runny, but I think this ranks up there among the best brunches we've had in Chicago. The sausage in both dishes was a surprise hit - could be the best sausage among those brunches. I also had a Jamaican coffee, which includes rum and kahlua. That was strong but delicious. My wife's bellini had pucker in it, so if you don't like pucker stay away from that one. The service was fast, friendly, and attentive, and the art inside is a lot of fun.
Fantastic (and inexpensive). I lived 13 years in the South, and this is the first good Southern place I've found up Nawth. Jambalaya was great!

Being the Southern Boy that I am, I was happy to find a place like Wishbone in Chicago!  I have a habit of ordering sweet tea everywhere I go and to get actual sweet tea puts a smile to my face!   I went here with David for brunch and was amazed by the selection of food on the menu.  I had to also try the Watermelon Lemonade they were serving that AM and it was awesome!  We both ordered an omelet and I had to try the cheese grits to see if they were good and it did not disappoint.  It was actually some of the best cheese grits I've had and much better than most places served in Atlanta!  I thought the biscuits were weird though...they weren't flaky or buttery...much more like a roll, but still good.   I'm not sure what all the fuss is about with the service, but we had some pretty good hospitality and didn't have to wait long to be seated or served our food.  Actually, I think I tipped more than normal since our waitress was way cool.  I would definitely recommend and it's a good substitute for us Southerners! :)

Now...I've been to the Wishbone in Lakeview for brunch and it was one of my better dining experiences.  BUT... I came to this Wishbone for a work lunch and from the minute we walked in I wanted to walk out.  The service was beyond SLOW for the fact that it was the lunch rush.  Now, I understand being overwhelmed, but I also know this is one of the usual go-to places for a lot of business folk.  Why this place wasn't prepared...I will never know. Walking through the door was the highlight of my lunch.  They messed up my order, when I got it it was cold...I've basically blocked out what it was but I remember thinking it was bland.  For a restaurant that's all about "southern" I found this odd. Don't do it.  I've still got a bad taste in my mouth.  Not good when it's a restaurant that gives it to you.

Where to begin... I have been going there for 2 years. The only thing positive I can say is that the server, KIM is the best ever!!! She is right on point with her friendliness and service. Actually, the bar tender Isaac is a gem too! Great drinks and soooo friendly! As for the other servers...There is a newer one, a bigger African American woman who has the most awful attitude toward everyone; patrons, other  servers and management! We have experienced that the last 3 times we were there.  We are always quick to compliment great service, figuring there is no use in even wasting energy on the bad service...BUT enough is enough already. She argues with other servers over your table, screams at co workers in the corner by the bar and is the queen of rolling her eyes and huffing and puffing when you as for something. Strangely enough, there is a heavy set Latina with a lot of eye make-up (Just want to describe her so you can be on watch for her when you go) She is the head hostess with the mostest! LOL She is also a big eye roller and G- forbid if you comment on the service. She is quick to defend, claiming, maybe she is having a bad day..Really, then she should have stayed home... Other servers show up just as you are being seated to ask if you are ready to place your order as if they didn't see the hostess seating the party. Once the order is placed, drink your coffee slowly because they ration out their coffee-only one cup per person! You see the server one more time when she/he brings the tab  to you and CHEERFULLY chirps, THANKS! COME AGAIN! HAVE A GREAT DAY! Too late to kiss ass, you should have brought napkins, refilled drinks, maybe even checked to see if the order was correct... When you speak with Lance, the manager, he just says, oh sorry, I'll have a talk...Yikes, good service man! Next time I will bug you for the refills and napkins.  The food is nothing to brag about. Everyone seems to brag about the biscuits and instant grits...if you are looking for home cooked food from the south, go to SWEET MAPLE ON TAYLOR STREET! Everything is delicious, home cooked and served with a smile and a laugh of two. Also, there is catfish on fridays for those of you who love fish. The mac and cheese is delicious. Food like your grandmother used to make. Give it a try and you will never return to Wishbone-especially not for their cruncy french toast, cooked in old oil, served sitting in grease...Good luck getting syrup for it!

Oh, no, no, no, no. no.  I proposed Wishbone for a business lunch, as my dining companion prefers "American" food, and I wanted to treat! Wishbone seemed like a grand idea, and I'd never been brave enough to endure the weekend brunch crowds. Southern cookin' is always sure to please! Still busy during lunch, but no wait. Lots of biz suits.  But, I cannot figure out why.  At all.  The food all around (3 of us) was...really, quite unappetizing. My asparagus salad was drenched in balsamic, and fabulously LIMP. Throw on a few overcooked asparagus spears, and we've got ourselves a TOTAL dud of a salad. Blech. Even the chicken was overcooked. I realize they don't specialize in salads, but don't do 'em if you can't do 'em right.  I thought maybe my guests would have better luck, but  both the veggie burger and the regular burger came on crunchy (stale?) buns that were 4 inches thick, square cheese melted on top (Holla McD's?) and the meat was greasy. I felt badly as they picked at it, wanting to be polite. Unfortunate. The sides were lackluster as well... Service: uninspired and it took millions of seconds to get our check. Refills were slow. I sat at the table for nearly 15 minutes before anyone even came over to say "hello." This ain't no Southern hospitality...it's not even Midwestern!  What's the deal with this place? Was it an off day? Should I be shunned for ordering salad at a place like this? Maybe, but I'm not huge on second chances, and Wishbone is likely off my "list" for good... Plusses:  Outdoor patio is covered, nice.  Valet parking. (street parking can be a bust) Fun interior, bright colors, lots of seating.  In the West Loop.

Cornbread. Ain't nothing wrong with that!*  Wishbone has a sweet, southern feel and yesterday was the perfect day for it - sitting outside on the patio under the lazy ceiling fans... summer perfection.  I went pure Louisiana with blackened catfish, mashed sweet potatoes, carrot salad, and, of course, cornbread.  I'll admit that I'm only recently coming around to the idea of cornbread - I wouldn't touch the stuff as a kid. Wishbone's cornbread is helping change my mind. Moist with the perfect touch of sweetness; I used it to mop up every last bit of sweet potato. Mmmm, perhaps I just didn't like my Mom's cornbread (sorry, Mama!).  I washed it all down with ice tea (not sweet tea, mind you, I'm not ready to completely relinquish all my Yankee values).  * In the words of my culinary adviser, Chris Rock.

I went to Wishbone on a Sunday, early afternoon. I have dined here several times, so I'm not a Wishbone newb ;) . It appeared to be crowded, but we were seated right away. So far, so good. Waiter came over, got our drink orders , and I ordered the Peppar Bloody Mary. Not a bad way to start the day so far. Then, things took a turn for the worst. We had to ask our server for water several times- seemed like the guy was overwhelmed; I observed people sitting nearby getting perturbed also. Food took over an hour to get out the kitchen - perhaps they were waiting for the chickens to lay the eggs first?. Long wait aside, I ordered crawfish cakes, with cheese grits and home style potatoes, along with biscuits. Overall, the food was good; I took a chance on the craw fish cakes- nice hint of spicy, not too hot; moist, plenty of meat; just the right portion size, with a decent hollandaise sauce over them. Potatoes were decent, but forgettable. Cheese grits, superb as usual. Not a bad place to go, but wish the service would have been better. Some places have their bad days, so that's what I'm chalking this up as.

A cool place with a good size patio--good for the summer when a lot of people want to eat outside. Too bad my partner was opposed to that. Bleh. The food is good, I had the Veggie Omelette- made with egg whites. Nice because places usually charge extra to have the egg white option. Came with potatoes and a corn muffin. Not really a fan of the muffin but the potatoes were good. My partner had the Crunch French Toast--this is a MUST HAVE! Out of all the brunch places I've been to- this is a first I'd ever seen. And totally ingenious! That crunch definitely compliments the toast, and it doesn't weigh the dish down and make it heavy. But remember- they close at 3pm on the dot! I got there the next day at 3:01 and they wouldn't seat us. I'll just have to dream about it until the next time I'm in Chicago.

I'm a big fan of Wishbone for brunch - spicy eggs, grits, the french toast, that delicious iced mudslide drink? Yum. Dinner is another story... I hadn't been to the West Loop locale for dinner in quite some time so when my friend and I ventured to Yats and saw that it was sadly closed, our hankering for Southern food led us to Wishbone. The service was fine. My sweetened iced tea was fine too, the food was a whole other story and that's really what you're coming for right? Yuckola. I attempted to be healthy and got the trout fillet with the pecan crust - very little meat and the hardly any sauce. The sweet potato side I got was candy sweet and the green beans were limp and a grayish green. Will I come back? Not for dinner at this Wishbone (the Lincoln Ave location has a better quality dinner) but probably for brunch.

It was an interesting first-time experience - the southern verandah style dining on the patio, the old-fashioned fans on the ceiling, the food itself. But definitely not something I'm going to bring guests to or crave to go back to.  We got the crunchy french toast - deep fried almost and so unhealthy. we also got the corn muffin, grit, and omelet. food was okay - service was actually great.

OMG, NEVER thought that I'd EVER have an experience like this at my beloved Wishbone.  I LOVE this place and this was an experience bad enough to make me second guess my undying allegiance to this place.  We walked up and they told us they'd put us on the list, but didn't give us a pager so we didn't get seated for 25 min.  No big deal.  Happens.  As soon as we brought it to their attention they seated us, so we totally got over it...  until we had to wait over 30 min to be greeted by our server.  And that was after we stopped an employee and asked who was our server...  Twice.  The first time, she stopped by and told us she was putting in an order and would be right over.  Yeah, we waited another 10ish min to see her after that.  By that point, I was a LITTLE bit upset.  I'm fine with waiting, just communicate with me for crying out loud!  Then, after 45 min, we got our waters and proceeded to wait for our food.  I suspect that she forgot to put in our order??  Either that, or the entire restaurant was sucking that day.  We asked to speak with the manager and she seemed not very interested in what we had to say, even though she SHOULD care that a loyal patron, two of them actually, were having an awful experience!  This makes me SUPER :-(.  Especially since I bring ALL of my visitors here.  Over 2 hours for a simple breakfast?!?!  It may be Toast on Damen from here on out...

I can't quite understand what the hype is all about. We had attempted to visit this spot on several occasions, but we were constantly greeted by very long lines just to put our name on the list. It's breakfast for cryin' out loud. I know many people cherish the first meal of the day and maybe that is why I just don't get it. Anyhow, my husband had heard rave reviews about this spot and I thought with all the lines - it must be pretty amazing.  This past Saturday we got up early and decided to check it out. We must have beat the brunch crowd as there was surprisingly no wait. I was very pleased. We were quickly seated and I began to look over the menu. Being a girl from the South my eyes immediately zoned in on the Sausage Gravy Biscuits. Oh, heavenly sausage gravy, I've been longing for you ever since my sister last made you at Christmas in '06. We placed our orders and our tummies rumbled with excitement of deliciousness we were about to feed it.  Service was sub-par, but the food arrived fairly quick. Both my dish and my husbands, Andouille Hash, seemed as if they had been made hours ago and sitting in back. The food was cold and not all that appetizing. We both doctored the plates to make them taste a little more to our liking. My husband adding hot sauce and me the black pepper. Once we finished we decided this was on the list of: no need to go back to restaurants. I am sure they won't miss our business one bit, but thought we'd share.

This morning, my date and I sat outside on the patio for an early brunch at Wishbone. Sun + Southern food = Vitamin D + fat = perfection. We split a Jambalaya Omelet with Cheese Grits and Biscuits and Gravy...all of which were the right amount of salty, greasy, creamy, and delicious.  Overall, a great way to simultaneously soak up alcohol from the night before and raise those HDL levels for super cheap. It was literally a $20 breakfast for two. Also, parking was shockingly easy to find in the West Loop. Fyi for those morning lushes: we tried to order a bloody mary but got shot down because the bar doesn't open until 10:30 AM. Hey Wishbone, the early birds need the booze most!

Love it!  A group of us went after Bike the Drive and had brunch.  We were seated quickly, even though it was packed.  I ordered the creamy cheese grits with shrimp.. completely off da chain!  The mimosa's were delish.  They also have a full bar, a definite plus!  Next day had the pancakes... fantastic!  My friend said she loved the french toast.  Sometimes the service is a little slow.  But overall, it can't be beat.  I'll definitely be heading back to the Wishbone.
gross low quality food.  What do people see in this pace that serves once frozen food?  Obviously something I don't.  This place is hyped up but the food is still garbage.

Everything I've gotten here has been great- the stuffed chicken, crawfish cakes, collard greens, sweet mashed potatoes, cornbread, bacon omelet, mmmmm. I took a star off because one waitress we had was a little too saucy for my tastes...but I added the star back because a waitress I had a few weeks later made up for it with her friendliness (chick with brown dreadlocks). Wish it wasn't a pain to park around here.

i can't rate the experience of actually dining here, since i never have.  this is based on the catered lunch i had at work one day.   after the guys came and set up all the food i asked the one what was vegan.  he told me the black bean cakes w/ mango chutney, the fruit salad & the green beans.  cool.  then he said the mashed potatoes & mac & cheese...  wait.. what?  i had a hard time believing that wishbone had secretly mastered the art of vegan mac & cheese (not to mention the buttery mashed potatoes) so i gave him a weird look.  he was like 'oh yeah theres milk & butter in them.. but ya know - you can always cheat.." umm.. if i wanted to cheat why the hell would i ask? btw- the black bean cakes w/ mango were good (spicy & really filling), the green beans were too oily, & the fruit salad was delicious.
love the food and the service~ fell in love with the corn bread  everyone should try it once~

Crowded on a a Sunday morning, but service was tip-top. Food was also good, although my plate was little light on eggs -- I got the Crawfish Cakes ($11) and eggs (scrambled), but what was supposed to be two eggs looked liek bareyl one to me. But saying that, I was plenty full and left half of one delicious(!) crawfish cake behind. Good corn muffin, too. Other folks enjoyed their breakfasts and the home fries were a hit. I should have gotten the grits. I love good grits! TIP -- Avoid the $8 valet parking and find a spot close by on the street. Plenty of spaces from what I could see. Valet service is pretty bad anyway.

Another place we order catering for 'budget' lunch several times a month, and as far as catering goes, they do a very good job.  Highlights: Hoppin jack (black beans and rice, w/sides of cheddar, diced tomatoes and scallions) Mac n' cheese....baked and crispy on top Wishbone salad, great light dressing and w/pine nuts. yum.  Crabcakes are great, and I'm told the crawfish cakes are as well...but crawfish creeps me out. The carnivores like their mango or bbq chicken. The corn muffins are okay, kind of dry and have onions in them which seems odd to me. Also not great is their caramel bread pudding thing.  I've also eaten here for breakfast and they do all the standards quite well. People swear by their cheese grits and bloody marys, and their coffee is nice and strong.

I recently went to Wishbone for lunch.  Overall, the food was great.  I had the salmon cakes with the sauteed spinach.  Everything was fresh.  The best thing for me was the strawberry lemonade.  It was awesome.  If you happen to order a drink from there, definitely try the Strawberry Lemonade. Its worth it.   The atmosphere was relaxing and very casual.  Its in a great location and the parking was decent so there was no worry about where to park.  Check it out.

I have eaten here for brunch for the past 2 saturdays, great comfort food.  I Love their grits with shrimp & mushrooms! Who would ever thought that combination would be so good.  Last week I ordered their catfish and cheese grits, the catfish was just ok, but the cheese grits were on point. Although, I'm from Virginia, I'm not a big fan of grits, but maybe I would be if I only ate here.    I like the ambiance too.

Say it with me... Cheese grits... cheese grits... cheese grits!  CHEESE GRITS! I love Wishbone!  This is one my absolute favorite places to go for Brunch, their best items being on the "lunch" side of the brunch.  I got salmon croquettes with poached eggs, cheese grits, and a biscuit... and damn, did I love it!  The croquettes were fresh and flavorful and my cheese grits weren't runny or hard... just perfect.  Ahhh.... They have a lot of traditional Southern Style breakfast items, even my super traditional African American parents approved, so I know it's good.  I love the comfort food, I love the atmosphere, but what I don't love is the insane crowd of people that descends upon the restaurant every Sunday for their brunch.  Fortunately, they have a bar, so if you're of age you can spend some time at the bar drinking their awesome mimosas or bellinis. I'll be back Wishbone... you better look out for me!  Cheese grits will be in short supply after I get done with you.

Ok, some of the best Bloody's in the city.  I would know, I've been a hunter of the best for the past year.  Very decent food and a splendid atmosphere.  Especially in the summer, they have biker deals too.  Snag a spot outside and enjoy the shade under their huge awning.

I go to Chicago at least 4 to 6 times a year and I always have one breakfast here or lunch.  It's comfort food.  You'll find something on the menu you will like. Comfortable, unassuming and basically regular folk type place.
