Went there for brunch this weekend, and it was packed at 10.30am! Great atmosphere and exciting menu. But the food was pretty underwhelming - we had the crawfish cakes and breakfast burrito - and we both felt like there was something missing in the dishes. It was also pretty expensive (the check came to 25 without tip) : for the area there are places where we can get breakfast for half the price that would be just as good! So it's quite the pity, since it seemed like such a nice place.

I really enjoyed dinner here while visiting Chicago. As soon as my local friend said "Southern food" I perked up and hoped for fried chicken. Lucky me, pan-fried chicken was on the specials that night, and it was super tasty, though the white meat was a little dry. The collard greens and cheesy mashed potatoes were perfect. As a bonus, they gave us chips and salsa to nosh on while we waited; unexpected and very nice, especially since the salsa was actually spicy. I love the fried egg lamps and the service was slightly slow but very friendly. Prices were very reasonable, especially considering the quantity of food. I'd definitely go back, especially since we didn't get to try the desserts.

3.5.  Awesome service, awesome atmosphere and impressive menu.  However, the food didn't wow me.  I got a soy mocha latte which was underwhelming (could have been that I'm just not used to soy product).  I ordered the red eggs, which were pretty good, but lacking in flavor.  My boyfriend got eggs benedict which were absolutely DOUSED in hollandaise... he seemed to like it, but I would have been disappointed if I had ordered it and it came out drenched.  He also ordered a side of apple gouda stuffed sausage.  It was about 3 bucks for one small sausage... really not cool. If in Chicago again, I will probably be back to try something else off the menu.  Perhaps I just didn't order well.

I went to this location two weeks ago after hearing all about this place.  Apparently during the summer there are lines out the door as people wait for a table on the weekends.  My question is...why?   I ordered the crunchy french toast which was decent.  Definitely crunchy and had a nice flavor but nothing that wowed me.  Service was friendly and I always enjoy eating at places that are crowded for breakfast.  There's something to be said about a place that has a buzz in the morning...it's a great way to get the day going! That being said, I'm still on my quest to find my favorite breakfast place in the city.  I'm glad I went to Wishbone and will probably go again eventually.  It's just not the type of place that I will attend regularly

We are pretty much regulars at Wishbone at this point, and I just wanted to update to say how much we enjoy this place.  The food is consistently excellent and it's just so nice to go to a reasonably priced place with great food where the staff is GENUINELY FRIENDLY.  It really lifts your spirits.  Go to Wishbone!

The bf and I went here today for Sunday Brunch, and it was unexpectedly great! There was a 20 minute wait for a table for two so we hopped right up to the bar and got seats. I ordered the crunchy french toast, and the bf had the crawfish cakes. Our order got "lost" and took a while, but I didn't care because I had a bloody mary in front of me. Our order being lost turned out to be a positive because when our food came out it was hot and fresh. Breakfast food gets funky fast! Our meals were very good! I wouldn't get the chicken sausage again, but I would get home fries. My bf and I agreed that it was the best french toast ever!

I just had a very nice lunch at Wishbone.  I ordered the BBQ pulled pork, with mac n' cheese and sauteed spinach as my two sides. The cornbread and the cole slaw were also wonderful.  Everything was very tasty and the service was quick and efficient.   I would easily go back.

Whattup - Wishbone?  If you read my review of your cousin over on Lincoln, you would be shocked I returned but alas, I have a heart. I went to meet a LARGE group for brunch (hint, show up on the later side so you don't have to wait so long and also enjoy the bar of bloody marys / mimosas / Irish coffees while you wait!). I thought they were moving the masses in and out efficiently enough. . .  When we sat down at the long table, the waitress was good - completely on top of her game. We didn't have to wait too long for the food either - I saw biscuits and gravy and catfish roll on by me. . . but I was waiting for my egg-white omelet and side of bacon. I went with the veggie omelet and was troubled to find potatoes in there. . . I mean they are on the side of the plate, do they need to be in the omelet too? And when you think "veggies", "potato" (unless you are living in Ireland) just doesn't pop up now does it?  Was the experience OK? Yes, yes it was. But I am just not sold on the food - there are MUCH better places to eat in Chicago for brunch and even lunch time meals. My wish is to go elsewhere next time, sorry :(

A friend of mine was visiting from out of state and my wife and I wanted to take him to a good southern style restaurant. If you ask anyone that lives in Chicago where to go they will probably tell you Harolds or Wishbone.  I chose Wishbone and found out it is all that is was cracked up to be. Here you are respected like family and the food tastes like it came out of momma's kitchen. I enjoyed the signature fried chicken dinner that came with my choice of two sides. Although, no decision was necessary for me because it had to be collards and sweet potatoes on the side. I also recommend the catfish sandwich.  The restaurant often posts new specials and one random discount you can get right now is the "low carbon imprint" reward. Bring in your helmet to eat any you get 15% off your entree. I like a place that knows what the community takes seriously and rewards them for being positive contributors to our society.

I have been here a number of times, but this was my first time sampling their brunch menu. After a careful inspection of the regular and special breakfast items, I'd like to think I had the following inner monologue: Wes: Hmmm...what should I get? Kid Wes: Crunchy French Toast! Wes: What? Kid Wes: You like French Toast! You like corn flakes! This is french toast AND corn flakes! ...and so I decided to give Crunchy French Toast a try.  Although not for lack of trying, it turns out that you can't combine things that you like, and always bring out what you liked in each individual component. In this case, I always liked the soft sweet taste of french toast, and the crunchy goodness of corn flakes. Combining the two negated what I liked about each: the french toast was no longer soft and tender, and the corn flakes added texture, but not necessarily crunchyness. It was certainly an acceptable dish, but certainly not the mind-blowing experience that Kid Wes was hoping for. That being said, I've always found Wishbone to be a delightful eating experience. I met a group of friends (with kids) today, we were able to get seating with minimal issues. (it's a lot tougher when the weather is milder of course!) They put out crayons and something to color for the younger ones, and have the wooden toddler seats if you need them and a kid menu. The coffee was okay, and the orange juice appeared to be of the fresh squeezed variety (or was at least priced that way). Service was acceptable and the food came out relatively quickly (under 10-15 minutes it seemed like). You can try finding street parking, but of course you can take advantage of their valet parking (at West Loop prices...$8).

Update:  I went there today for breakfast with my friends again and I understand that it's a busy holiday weekend - CALL IN MORE PEOPLE TO WORK.  NEVER should I have to wait for an hour for pancakes AFTER I sit down and order. If there's going to be an hour wait, say so at the door and I will find someplace else to eat.  Considering my boy had a plane to catch this afternoon, we notified them that we were cancelling the order.  They said they'd send the manager over.  Five minutes later the manager was still not there.  I left a $5 on the table to pay for my now warm milk that was meant to be had with my hot pancakes and for my boy's coffee and we bounced.  I'm sadly disappointed with the service today, whether the place was packed or not.  This could have been preempted by saying 'the food's probably going to take a bit longer today' and I would have happily said no thanks and gone elsewhere.  Besides the food is decent, but not the greatest.  Epic fail on the service.  Never have I left a restaurant, HUNGRY, no less because my food took too long to be served. After a series of delays in hanging out due to various persons running on CPT (if you don't know what it means, don't ask), I finally got together with my friend and his friend this morning for breakfast.  The choice was Wishbone. I had classic fare of pancakes and Zo had banana pancakes and his friend the shrimp and grits.  He got up to take a phone call and me and Zo almost bogarted his bowl...we would have been sitting there licking the spoon clean had he not returmed quickly.  Well, you know, I just didn't want his food to get cold!  I also had a side of potatoes...well about a 1/4 of a side since Zo made short order of those... (I'm just messing with you)  Anyway, Breakfast was solid and everybody was full and happy by the time we left.  I've had better breakfasts (as I consider myself a connoisseur) but this was pretty good.

Redemption-- is the word I am going to give Wishbone. I had lost a lot of faith in their food. My blackened catfish, black eyed peas, and sweet potatoes were fantastic. Nice portions and the Sangria that was $ 4.00 was fantastic. They have redeemed themselves with me however our waitress was too busy gossiping and missed the most important thing...keeping our glasses full. We had to go get our check and glass of water from her because she was just gabbing away to the other workers. I am all about having fun at work but damn not letting your guest wait because you need to find out the latest. Get it together girlfriend !!!!

Yum Wishbone!  Let's start with a spicy delicious bloody mary and then talk about the cheese grits.  I could end there because they are both divine.  But I'll carry on... I have had many of the dishes and been thrilled with everything.  Bring it on!

I had the andouille hash for breakfast today--pretty good.  Prices are reasonable, got in quickly and all the staff (they were everywhere) was friendly.  Food was good and I'll go here again to try the barbeque.

It's funny. I can't tell you how many times I have driven right by this place without ever giving it a second glance. Maybe cuz it is better known as a breakfast place than a dinner hangout.  But on a recent Sunday morning- I had a chance to experience what many on here rave about- southern style cooking.  I had been given a couple of hints on what to order prior to eating here from someone who had been here several times. "Try the shrimp n grits or the southern benedict", says he and so with that as my mantra, I entered the restaurant.  The place was packed but we scored a table right away which was pleasantly surprising. Our server hurried over and within moments orders were taken and anticipation began.  I ordered the southern benedict (picture eggs benedict except for biscuits instead of muffins and sausage gravy instead of hollandaise). The gravy was great but the biscuit tasted a bit dry. Also- it came with potatoes but I was totally done with my eggs before the server could find me ketchup to go on the potatoes-and this was after several requests.  I also think that had the timing been better at the bar- I might have had more than one bloody mary. It just took so long to get the one that I was hesitant to order another.  Maybe it was just an off day. Or maybe I should have ordered the shrimp and grits. Either way- Wishbone is an okay choice for brunch. I've just got others in town that put all the pieces together better and in the morning I need all the help I can get.

Great place for southern style food.  I've been here multiple time and this place has not disappointed me yet.  I've had their blackened cat fish, pulled pork, baby back ribs, cole slaw, corn bread and collared greens, all delicious and at reasonable prices!

I love this place.  I don't think I've ever had to wait for a table, not sure how I've managed that.  They have a nice variety of food, and breakfast-y alcohol.  Cheese grits are very yummy.  Though their biscuits aren't always consistent.  But they have chicken sausage which I love.

Average, but not authentic Southern food. Sorry, folks. This is not really authentic Southern food, but it will do. I guess. I do not understand all the hoop-la about this place. It is often crowded and the dishes are kind of bland. The drinks are good, the employees are great, and food - just average. If you venture to "less popular neighborhoods" in Chicago, you will find real Southern food... and this is not "soul food".

I went here with my best friend wanting to try a new restaurant. I found it in my handy dandy Time Out Chicago Guide Book I bought. So needless to say I was really excited to put it to use. Anywho... I must say the staff was very friendly and being that it was a Tuesday night, there was no wait. Everyone seems to be giving rave reviews about the cheesy grits so my friend ordered them as an appetizer. Neither of us cared for them and were in fact quite disappointed.  We both ordered drinks. I got my normal Cosmo and he got the Electric Lemonade. Both drinks were very strong. Mine tasted like straight vodka. But I felt like I got my money's worth in that sense.  For dinner, I ordered the meat loaf with the rosemary gravy. For my sides I got the Mac & Cheese and the greens. The meatloaf was mediocre. The mac & cheese was ok. I make better at home. The greens tasted like they had a tad too much vinegar in them but were still tolerable.  My friend had the pulled pork, which was really the only BBQ thing on the menu and he LOVES his BBQ. However he was slightly disappointed when his plate just had a bunch of pulled pork on it and no sauce. They served the BBQ sauce in a little cup on the side. For his sides he got the mac and cheese and the home fries which he found to be just ok.  We both agree that the best part of the whole meal were the corn muffins. I could have just eaten those and left happy. They were quite yummy.  Even though we were both pretty full, we couldn't resist trying the desserts. I had the praline cheese cake which was totally homemade, definitely not made somewhere else or out of a box. The praline topping was very tasty. I should have gotten some coffee to go with it. My friend ordered the bread pudding and said that it was very good.  All in all, I was a little disappointed. I expected more options and better food. I don't see myself running back there anytime soon. I might give it another shot just for the cheesecake and the corn muffins. Those two things and the friendly staff--3stars.

Basic Southern food - can't complain at these prices. Wishbone is a big, busy, high-turnover restaurant convenient to the Loop.  Low prices keep it busy anywhere near a meal time.  The service is ok, the food is ok at best.  Atmosphere is crowded and rushed.  This is a decent stop for a square meal of Southern cooking.  But if you want the word "cuisine" added, this isn't the place.

Eh.   That word sums up my entire dining experience.  I got the biscuits and gravy thinking that they would be amazing--they do tout themselves as a Southern restaurant, after all.  They weren't amazing and the service wasn't either.  I guess they were some of the BETTER biscuits and gravy in the city, but that says little.  I am also not big into the Soul Food thing, so I doubt I will be back.

To start off, it may have been a mistake to go to Wishbone for dinner.  They really seem to be known for brunch, and I can see how the large, airy dining area would be nice in the daytime.  For evening, they change the atmosphere by dimming the lights, giving the place the feel of an under-lit cafeteria.  The attempt at romantic lighting just seemed out of place in this setting. The food itself was a huge disappointment.  First up was the shrimp and grits (a favorite dish of mine from the south).  Wishbone's version consists of un-cleaned shrimp and canned mushrooms swimming in a gravy-esque sauce over a bed of soggy grits.  It frankly grossed me out, and I couldn't stomach more than a couple of bites.  For main dishes, we ordered the jambalaya stew and the black bean cakes.  The jambalaya is definitely more of a stew than the thick rice-based dish it is in Louisiana.  It tasted more like tortilla soup than anything else.  The black bean cakes were tasteless and bland.     In fact, all of the food we tasted at Wishbone was extremely BLAND--and seemed to be completely lacking in seasoning.  The one bright spot of the evening was the mashed sweet potatoes with nuts, which have a good natural flavor and a nice texture.  I might try this place again for brunch, but in general I just feel let down.

This place make me want a micro-Yelp category where I can just Yelp one dish - shrimp grits - five stars for you alone. Creamy cheddar cheesy grits with a saucy  cream and wine gravy of sorts with bacon, green onions and shrimp. Jee-sus! This is just one of the best things I've ever put in my mouth. Every time I've gotten anything else I am just mad at myself, because I don't like anything else at Wishbone after a lot of trying - there is just a lot of spotty food quality here and a lot of nuttin special - but this is one of my favorite dishes in the city so there is a serious quandary, but the shrimp grits win out frequently. The restaurant itself has a lot of cool folkish art and visitors are really impressed by it - a lot of people seem to like the food here - I'd suggest not trying to front and pretend you like it because Oprah likes it and you want to seem cool (and you feel her right around the corner, maybe looking at you....) - just stick to the shrimp grits.  Order the shrimp grits at night - it's listed as an appetizer, but you get the same portion as in the morning, but for like a dollar or two less.  If it's not enough to fill you up then just get some more shrimp grits, nothing else here is really very worth it.

Vodka. Cheesy shrimp & grits. Strawberry lemonade. Seriously. I should just be able to stop there. That's 5-stars, right? You mean there's more? Muffins and biscuits and... No. I am gonna stop here, at least with the food. My 1st time in here was several years ago. It was a Friday, I recall. I'm almost certain I ate something - though this was before I discovered the secret of the shrimp and grits being on the dinner menu as an appetizer for less than breakfast but for the same size. Anyway, a noon lunch turned into the start of a Lost Weekend in which I was happily overserved in the best kind of way. Thank goodness I walked over from work and hadn't left necessities back at the office. Needless to say, Wishie has a special place in my heart.

I think my breakfast on Saturday morning might have been good if I had just come in and had it on Thursday when it was made.  After hearing such good things about the breakfast here and having come in a few times for lunch and dinner we were really looking forward to checking out Wishbone.  Things were so bad I don't know if I can go back for lunch or dinner any more out of principal.   I will say this the coffee was good and it was some of the coldest carrot juice I have ever had, however, everything else including the Lady's food really seemed like it was made hours not minutes before we ordered it.   I got an omelet and grits, which I love but always have trouble finding.  Let's just say that Waffle House does a better grits without questions.  My omelet looked like our waitress jumped a Delta Airlines stewardess, stole her offerings, dropped it on a plate and set it in front of me.  I figured the Jambalaya omelet would at least have decent flavor but it was just dry chicken and flavorless peppers inside what looked like a two egg wrap.  Some salsa or something might have saved it but it just looked terrible too.  My grits had that film that gravy and pudding get on top of them and were just plopped on my plate, I hate being reminded of my time in prison but their presentation brought me back a bit.   The lady's biscuits and gravy had the similar film on it and were equally terrible.  The sausage they use in the gravy is good, if only the gravy were warm it might have changed things.  We also decided to try the Apple Sausage which also might have been good if it were hot but sadly it was not. The strange thing is we didn't wait long for our food so I find it bizarre that they could have prepared it and some how allowed it to get that cold prior to bringing it to our table.  The whole situation was really peculiar. Service is decent for such a high volume place.  My lunch and dinner experiences feel like they took place at an entirely different restaurant even though I sat in the same booth once before. Wishbone I think someone threw a Monkey Bone in the Wrench. RrL
Yummy food.  Quite a wait.  Won't seat you till your entire party is there and won't split checks.

Went here for brunch....very good. Service was awful. We asked our waitress 4 times for some water! And she wasn't even busy... had to go to bar for water. But the food was delicous and my bloody mary was the best I ever had. Would go back .

Being a brunch snob, I suppose my rating (3) of this place is a bit harsh - considering my dining experience that occurred this morning was quite pleasant.  Really, it was.  But I've had better egg-white spinach omelet, home fries, grits, crunchy toast, hot chocolate, etc....  The stuff I ate here this morning was standard, nothing outstanding. I could perhaps give it an additional half-star for the friendly service.  Despite how packed and busy this place is, I didn't feel rushed about all by the staff.

This is a review of the catering. We ordered from wishbone for my sons baptism this past weekend. The food arrived warm and on time. They were able to accommodate our requests which was a blessing. The food was not your traditional buffet which really impressed our guests. They absolutely loved the mac and cheese!! We even had left over side dishes that some of our guests took home.

I wanted to love this place.  My family had very good dishes, at least they said so, but my mac and cheese was dried out and hard.  I think I'll go back and give it another try because the cornbread was delicious.  Maybe they were having a bad mac and cheese day.  It wasn't for me.
I'm not a fan of this place.  The food was bland and the atmosphere had no energy.

Food Shrimp and grits? Yes, please. Thank you. Jumbalaya? Yes, please. Thank you. Gumbo? Yes, please. Thank you. Cornbread muffins? UH, YES PLEASE!!! AND THANK YOU VERY MUCH!!! Service Friendly host? Yes, please. Thank you. Friendly server? Yes, please. Thank you.

Two words: Corn. Cakes. On my most recent visit for brunch, I tried the corn cakes with a side of bacon -- holy cow!  I had everyone at my table begging for a bite & wishing they had ordered the same.  Waits are expected, but they move fairly quick, and the patio is also a nice option.

My man friend and I had our first Wishbone experience at the Pitchfork Music Festival a few years back.  Since that first bite we were hooked.  Now we make sure to stop in for a monthly Wishbone fix.  I've tried something different every time, and while it's all good I would suggest the Carolina carb cakes to any first timers.  DELICOUS! The service is virtually impeciable; fast, curteous, and with just the right dab of sass.  The decor is clever and loaded with humor. With slightly nutty art work all over the place. Maybe it's because I'm a Southern girl but, if it weren't for the slightly pricey menu, I'd eat here breakfast, lunch AND dinner.

Wishbone's got some sick ass crunchy french toast! I'm not from Chicago, but I loved this place so much the first time, i had to come back on my second trip. My boyfriend wanted to try a new place, but I just knew I needed to re-live my first ever crunchy french toast experience. Everything else on the menu is so-so, I had a light spinach omelette to go with it and it was a little on the bland side, but what can i say, it was light. The homefries that go with each dish are delish - you taste the lovely aroma of spices they put into it in each bite. it's a great soul food place with great personality - there was a witty sign posted when i was there advertising debate night at the restaurant on their big screen and wish i were still going to be there for it. one other thing that stood out is they give out low carbon footprint rewards to those who arrive on bicycles - thoughtful!

I've only had breakfast foods here, so no idea how the regular food is. The milkshakes are good, as are the hashbrowns. The corn flake (or maybe it was frosted flakes) french toast is, umm, odd.  Not bad, but not amazing either.  The black bean cakes are fine, but what I really come here for is the corn cakes with a red pepper sauce--I love them! (I do wish the red pepper sauce was hotter, but there's tabasco on the table, so...) It's very crowded on the weekends though, so if you're looking for brunch and don't want to wait for ages, go early or later. 1:30 on and you're fine, early is also okay, but 11 on it's a zoo.

You cannot lose at Wishbone! The service is quick and attentive. The food is southern style comfort food. From grits to crab cakes, I have never disliked anything I have ordered. The coffee is even above average. Go a little before the regular lunch hour to avoid the crowd and if you're thinking about a Sat or Sun, go EARLY! The line gets pretty intense.

OK, so I see lots of people writing pretty good reviews of this place, and I even have close friends who say it's great, but the two times I've been there I just haven't gotten good/great food.  I look at the items on the dinner menu, and the descriptions start out sounding good, but then they end up adding strange ingredients that just screw the whole package up.  Maybe it's just the place to go for brunch/lunch (my only experiences have been with dinner), but if my dinner experiences are anything to go by, I'll be staying away.  Sorry, guys...
my ole weekend brunch fave! love some shrimp & cheese grits.  great place to get a southern food fix.

This place is an old favorite for weekend brunch and even if a lot of people think it is boring or no longer novel, to me it is tried and true.  It is a favorite place to bring out-of-town guests, who tend to be impressed because their breakfast menu includes quite a few unusual offerings, especially for Northern cities.  From crab cakes to black bean cakes to cheese grits, I just love their selection and always have a hard time choosing from their menu.   I can't really say anything about their lunch or dinner menus, since I don't recall the last time I was here for dinner.  It's a popular place, so at peak brunch times, there will be a wait,.  But there are a lot of seats and the service is generally pretty fast.

Lunch is best at Wishbone If there is one thing I've learned during my life it's that anyone can scramble an egg and it won't cost you $4. Breakfast is the cheapest meal of the day, but restaurants charge you more per ingredient than they do for lunch. Skip the breakfasts and the brunches [especially the latter, anywhere] and find great places for lunch. Like Wishbone. If you're within the 10 block radius, Wishbone is worth the walk, especially Saturday lunch. This assumes you like or wish to try Southern fare. Start with a hoe cake, truly! The hoe cake is served with a medley of grilled vegetables and the ubiquitous red pepper sauce over cheesy grits. Save the black bean cake and [low country] North Carolina crab cake for future visits. Play your Southern foods hand correctly and go with a traditional dish prepared in a traditional style. You will get a much better feel for the food and the talents in the kitchen if you go with Crawfish Cakes and leave the Peppercorn Filet to someone else. Sides are many and generous. Again, choose wisely.

I have not been to Wishbone for a while.  I missed them when they closed for remodeling.  But once again I had a great meal and enjoyed the service.  I am happy to be back there and hope to schedule more meetings at Wishbone.  My only wish it that they served their lentil soup more often and more variation in their soups.  But my meal, the spinach salad and my firend who had the catfish was great!

One of my favorite things to do is meet friends at Wishbone for weekend brunch.  Sometimes we have to wait for a table, but the service is excellent.  They have a large menu, and I HIGHLY recommend the corn cakes with a side of steamed spinach.  Mmm.  My mouth waters just thinking about them.

I've been here a couple of times, and I've never been disappointed.  Unlike its Lakeview counterpart, there's barely a wait for dinner.  Last time I was there, I tried the North Carolina style crab cakes.  They were tasty, though I'm not sure what makes them "North Carolina" style, since I'm pretty sure crab cakes are Maryland's claim to fame.  Then again, I guess you can't have a Southern restaurant serving Yankee crab cakes.   The highlight of the meal, though, was the Margarita flight!  Three generous servings of lime, strawberry, and mango margaritas--$15!  Be prepared to walk out wobbly.

Bean cakes. Particularly inspired home fries. A biscuit that looks like a roll but tastes unmistakably like a biscuit. Minus one point for the old guy I walked in on in the restroom. "I couldn't work the latch!" he rationalized.

I absolutely love Wishbone.  There is nothing better than waking up on a Sunday morning and heading over to this place.  This isn't just your regular breakfast joint.  This is amazing southern-style cooking. You can generally expect a 10-15 minute wait for brunch on the weekends,  but this is never a problem for me when I have one of their yummy bellinis in my hand.  Plus, the decor is very entertaining.  I highly recommend Wishbone to anyone looking for a great breakfast!

The place is like a brunch factory.  Gigantic space, people everywhere.  The food was average at best.  Sure, there are items with a Southern twist, like the crawfish cakes with corn muffin that i ordered.  The idea is good, but the execution is , meh.  the cakes were small and dry and overcooked.  We also tried the crunchy french toast.  Again, sounds tasty, but the ultimate product was basically toast coated with corn meal and then deep fried.  First few bites were good, but then it got to be really greasy.  but the coffee was acceptable, and the waiter was really nice, despite it being super busy on a Sunday morning.  overall, it was ok.  but with so many great brunch places to go in Chicago, why bother going back?

A favorite, I also like to take visitors from out of town here, they enjoy it.  So far my favorites are the pulled pork & the grits, love the menu.  The key lime pie has me bursting but how can I say no.  4 stars because the service has been spotty, but never bad.   A great time!

The food is good, the coffee isn't. The service was good too and we went at a very busy time. If you can get a seat outside on a nice day I think it is worth the wait. The fried potatoes are really good - although probably not good for you. The spicy bean patties with mango sauce are ok, but seem dry and not that spicy. I also had scambled eggs which were good. I have been to Wishbone at the other location and have always liked it. It is comfort food with a little twist.

10-10-10. That's how long it took for verything to happen. We were seated and we didn't get menu's for 10 minutes. 2 of them for 6 people? 10 minutes later, she came for our drink order and food. Except she didn't ask for our drinks. she asked if they for get our drinks? Lady, you never took the order. The restaurant was empty. All the customers were outside on the patio. As I unwrapped the airline silverware, I saw that my fork was pointed north and south? Do people really steal that much that you need to use this crap. The food. I had the bb-q brisket, it was very tender and the sauce was nice and smokey. But the sides. The mac and cheese had no taste. The french fries? They were cubed potatos sauteed in onions? The blackened chicken had no taste. The fish was the same way. Did we pull up to shady acres and not know it? I have been here several times before, with no problem. This is my last.

Does anybody else think it's hard to find a good, old fashioned, American iced tea in Chicago? I mean, all it is is Lipton black pekoe and water... Come on! But, on the balance I've found it next to impossible for something not to be wrong with a Chicago iced tea. Wishbone gets it right and that's a check in their favor from the get go. #2 is the kick-rear corn bread which could serve as my entire meal. So, with those 2, I'm totally good with Wishbone. "But, what about the food," you ask? It's pretty good. It seems a little faux Southern to me as I always wonder why it's so hard to find barbecue on the menu and "Virginia" and "Vegeterian" are two words that don't seem to go together in the Virginia Vegetarian Sandwich, so the menu does not quite match the premise but, all in all, it's fine. The Jambalaya was mediocre when I tried that out, but the beans and rice looked positively heart stopping on a friend's plate and I was drooling over that. My hamburger on the most recent visit was fulfilling. Worth a visit. 3.5 stars (I really want half stars here.)

In my quest for the ultimate Biscuits & Gravy in Chicago (ok, let's just go with "respectable" as I believe ultimate will never happen, sadly) I came across Wishbone.  It had been a loooong time since eating here, try like 8 or so years and only did lunch back then, and it was good iirc.   So this review is based solely on their B&G's and I'm gonna give them the "best of Chicago" up to this point.  They are solid. Very good as a matter of fact.  They have the best sawmill gravy i've tasted since, well, probably since the one's my Mom made several years ago; and if you've read any of my B&G reviews, you'll know that hers are the absolute standard bearer, the best ever, and have had none in the world that even come close to hers.   Wishbone's gravy itself is pretty much perfect though, really nice; creamy and smooth consistency, with just the right amount of heat at the end (which sort of creeps up on you).   Not overly spicy, and defo not too mild.  Their gravy is a sausage gravy and instead of "crumbled" sausage they just cut up pieces of sausage patties, which to me, is ok but my preference is the crumbled variety.  Finally the biscuits.  Again, very very good.  Light, fluffy, beautiful texture and perfect moistness....4.5/5 on the biscuits.  The search for the ultimate B&G continues but i'll definitely be back to Wishbone for their version in the future, no doubt about it.

Had the luck of visiting Wishbone during Memorial Day weekend when it was nearly empty by Wishbone standards. I ordered the French Toast with a side o' ham, my partner in crime ordered the Kentucky Fried Eggs, bacon and potatoes. My ham looked like it was leftover from Easter dinner and had been microwaved every weekend in hopes some sucker would actually eat it! Well, I was that sucker and it wasn't the succulent side that the bacon was. Next time I'm there I'll have the KF Eggs (peppers, onions, spices), bacon (how do they get it crispy and chewey at the same time?) and potatoes (what is that, Mrs. Dash?- yum!). I noticed when we sat down that our server was being reminded to bring waters a 2nd time by the table next to us, so I pre-emptively made sure she didn't forget our waters or anything and then ran off not to be seen. Service was adequate for the price range. I'm not expecting a waiter in black and whites for breakfast.

This is the closest thing I've found to Southern food here, and I scarfed everything down because I was excited to see a place at least attempt real Southern cuisine. They also attempted sweet tea. There was nowhere near enough sugar in it, but damn it was close enough. I ordered the bbq. I figured it would be bad, but surprisingly it wasn't completely awful. It was North Carolina style which, to anyone unfamiliar with it, means that it isn't anywhere as good as Memphis style. But I took a risk and went for it. It wasn't so bad. Apparently, you get a choice of bbq sauce or some vinegar sauce. I went with the bbq sauce and it was so full of vinegar that I wouldn't want to taste the other one.  The mashed potatoes were good, but it's pretty hard to mess those up. The baked beans tasted like they were from out of the can, but that didn't really bother me. I also had a bite of the peach cobbler and one of the chocolate desserts. I normally don't like peach cobbler, but I thought this was pretty good. The chocolate dessert, of course, was delicious. I fully intend on coming back, but with my far superior Memphis-style bbq sauce. Yummy.

Wishbone has been my spot for breakfast for a while, but, I've never cared for their coffee.  It has an odd (lemony?) after taste to me; the regular and the decaff. Now that Mr. Funky, that's my dranky drank! If anyone else reading this agrees (re:  coffee), please let me know.

I dream about this place often and my first visit to the establishment was much like a dream. We had the Shrimp & Grits and Crunchy French Toast and have tried since our initial weekend brunch visit in January 2006 to reproduce the awesomeness in our Austin home. The mister has come very close to creating the experience and deliciousness of the Shrimp & Grits -- no such luck with the French Toast. This place...this place is a reason to visit Chicago.
This one became an instant favorite, the whole fam liked it. First time I had shrimp and grits; I know I had the same thoughts at first but it was pretty good. Prices are pretty good too.

Wow, outdoor seating! You'd think it would take some restaurants forever to figure out (see: Le Peep). I love outdoor seating! It's so amazing especially when it's the warmest day ever after our five months of winter.  Our service was pretty good, and I had the steak & eggs with biscuits and gravy. I was surprised at how descent the steak was because it was pretty cheap.  There were no carafes of orange juice here, and the orange juice by the glass was pretty pricey (something like 2.50 or 2.79 if I remember correctly).  Back to the outdoor seating thing... Best to take a jacket as only some of the tables actually get the warming sun and the others get the shade with crazy breezes. No complaints though.

What is it with the crab cakes here? I tried them a while back, and they were OK, just like service was OK. But the group we came with made Wishbone fun and quite a riot (maybe that explains the service ?!)  Before all this, we drove around in circles for 30 minutes trying to find the place... passing up Harpo productions so many times we were ill. I haven't been back since.

This place is delightful. We went on a Saturday night and were seated right away. They have an interesting beer selection and the prices are great. The cornbread muffins are the best I have ever had in my whole life, and they gave us seconds!  I had the crabcakes with spinach and mashed potatoes. I ate every bite and wished I had more spinach, the flavors were really vibrant and delicious. My companion had a steak and "special potatoes" and collard greens. The special potatoes were identical to my mashed potatoes but good nonetheless. All that food and two beers for $40. Not bad for a Saturday night downtown.

Any place where I can eat crab cakes and drink bellinis for breakfast is 5 stars in my book.  Food was good and large portions.  The drinks were good as well.  They had some hard to find beers which was nice.  Service was a little iffy.  Our server would disappear for long periods of time and we needed some new drinks which was disappointing.

Went here for lunch a few weeks ago and I thought it was pretty good. I was expecting more of a typical cafe, I didn't realize it was southern/cajun food. But, I was pleasantly surprised. I got the blackened chicken breast - and everything comes with two sides... I chose the mac and cheese and the sauteed spinach, but there were a lot of options! The friend I was with got the chicken with the mango salsa, and it looked AWESOME as well. We both finished our whole plate. Our waiter was super friendly and the service was good. Price was really reasonable, and you get a lot for your money. Haven't been for breakfast, but I definitely would go back. Neat place.

This place is a treat for lunch during week.... I'm in love with the black bean cakes and mango salsa.  The corn muffins are to die for and all of the sides are delicious. I can't really say anything bad about this place.  There is lots of seating inside, and they make an outdoor shaded patio in the warmer weather.  Service is good and attentive but not overbearing.  And everything I have ever ordered, as well as whoever I'm eating with, has not disappointed. I have never been her for brunch, mainly because I can't seem to get out of my house to spend money on food Sundays (and volunteer all day on Saturdays) but I'm sure it's just as good and tasty. We're going to have Wishbone cater a party next month - I can't wait to have their delicious food off site!
Went here for brunch and enjoyed it. They had a wide range of items on the menu and the food was all very good. The omelettes were very good and the homefries were tasty as well.

Just love this place, I have eaten here twice. It's a pleasant 15 minute walk from my office. I love that I can get seated right away at noon on a Friday. Not noisy, so great place to lunch with your friends and talk. Service is always great.  I had the Jambalaya and the mango lemonade. The lemonade was a delicious surprise.

I'm a big fan of brunch, especially on a Sunday afternoon. Wishbone is one of my faves and everything that we ordered my first time there was fabulous! I fell in love with the delicious french toast and my brother raves about the cheese grits (hey-maybe it's a 'guy' thing?). Oh and we went on Easter Sunday and only had to wait maybe 15 minutes if that, which was impressive! The server was super friendly and I loved the ambiance on a lazy Sunday afternoon. I would recommend this place for brunches and look forward to going back with a group of friends.

I'm a big brunch fan and this is one of my faves.  The Peppar Bloody Mary is fabulous, but I really go for the cheese grits and corn muffins.  Yummy.  Sometimes the rest of the meal is a bit "meh" ergo the 3 stars.

Yes! Get an egg with cheese grits with spinach, toast, and you're done. Get corn pancakes with a couple of sides and some meat, and you're double done. I've only been for brunch, but if you want a nice heavy meal to settle the constitution I can hardly imagine better food to eat.

I was a little skeptical after the mixed reviews, but I had a great meal here. And pretty good service too. We got seated right away for a Sunday brunch (maybe cuz we were only a party of 2, there were lots of people waiting for a table). I had the crab cakes special and also tried my friend's blackened catfish. Try the corn muffin. The coffee was pretty good too (dark). Yay! I'll be back.

This place is great if you have kids to entertain. My nephews and niece came to visit so we took them around 6 p.m. and the staff was very accommodating. The kids were given crayons and their portions were split before they came out of the kitchen. Sans kids, I love this place for brunch too.

Was in the area so stopped for breakfast.  Usually go to the Lakeview location and was THRILLED that there wasn't a wait for a table at 10 on a Sunday morning.  AWESOME! Menu was the same as Lakeview so I ordered my fav Kentucky Scramble -- scrambled eggs with peppers and onions and potatoes on the side.  It was great.  And the food came out in such a short amount of time.   Although we easily found street parking, they have valet which i saw a lot of people using because it was so cold outside.
Very yummy but very fattening! I have only been to Wishbone a few times for breakfast but every time it was soooooooooo yummy! Definitely comfort food.

As an Olympic Bruncher, I've seen the better and the worse Chicago has to offer. I was pretty impressed with my first trip to this particular Wishbone, a visit well overdue. Seated quickly at 10:30 on a Sunday, and our server was fast, attentive, and NICE even though it was packed. Most importantly, the food delivered. I had the much-discussed Crunchy French Toast which was excellent...simple but very good.  Their booze assortment was ok, but not fantastic. The Bloody Mary I had was jacked full of black pepper, a lazy way to blow out your mouth with heat. Not that great, but no big deal. I'll definitely be back...AND, at around the same time. Looks like if you're rolling in later than 10:30ish on a Sunday, good luck.

This is one of my favorite brunch spots.  The omelettes are great as are most things on the menu. It is southern style, but for those who don't enjoy that, there are most things. My boyfriend loves the rice and beans ( I know, sounds funny for breakfast), but its actually really good. Its a big place so there isn't usually a wait. In the summer they have a great patio.  Definitely worth checking out if you like great brunch!

I always recommend Wishbone to anyone looking for a great place for breakfast.  Their biscuits and gravy are amazing, and I love the crunchy french toast.  Service is always fast and friendly.  If going for breakfast on the weekend, I recommend trying to get there before 9:30 a.m. otherwise you'll have to wait a while for a seat.  In the summer, the outside patio is great!

I do remember the days when Wishbone was the hot spot for brunch and even lunch... But, I feel like it has just turned into a touristy generic restaurant, with disgruntle employees and factory churned out food. Totally and completely mediocre. I get the feeling they make a bunch of stuff in back, plop it on a plate and it sits there....if someone orders it they bring it out. Sorry Wishbone...there's just too many great restaurants out there...

I liked the mashed sweet potatoes.  That's about it.  The service was non-existant.  Seriously.  I was going to send back part of my meal, but the waiter never came back to our table before our plates were cleared.  My grilled chicken with mango salsa was not half as good as it sounds.   The place was half empty on a Friday night.  Now I know why.

While I have not had Wishbone for dinner is quite some time, a few years, I have had brunch there more times then I can count.  Overall, Wishbone is kitchy, affordable, and quite tasty. Food:  As I remember it, the blackened catfish was really good.  The crispy french toast was not my thing, but very good.  While I would not order it again my boyfriend was obsessed with how good it was.  Overall the breakfast items are consistently good.  The price is right. Drink:  Coffee is kind of bitter, but it does the trick.  Skip the OJ.  I have never had a cocktail here, so I have no opinion on their bar. Atmosphere: Bright, airy, tongue-in-cheek. I like the crazy ass pictures of chickens.  This place has a cool, comfortable feel.  Very diverse, no one would feel uncomfortable here... except maybe an Evangelical...  At times for brunch there is a wait, but I have never waited longer then 15 minutes.  Granted, I don't roll in until after 11:30am. Service: It can be slow at times, but for the most past I have never had a problem. Closing:  Everyone should have brunch here at least once.  It is worth the trip and is becoming a Chicago staple.  I can't wait to try the one in Berwyn...  But that is probably because I am oddly obsessed with Berwyn..........

I haven't done the brunch here, but it is pretty famous.  Oprah and Patti LaBelle, ya know?  (Patti LaBelle, totally wrote the mac n' cheese recipe, for reals) The food is amazing on all counts.  The kitchen is fast and consistent.  They frequently serve Crawfish Etouffette as a dinner special, and that's one of my favorite dishes.  The pecan pie is Out. Of. This. World. Ok, I'll be honest.  I haven't dined here as a customer.  I'm a server there on nights and weekends.  But the food IS really good.  And the prices ARE really reasonable.  And, I work there, so c'mon down, and with all the cash you save on your meal, Tip your Server!

I'm a wishbone fan from way back, especially the original on Grand, but I had lunch there the other day and it was a mediocre experience.  The service and food on Lincoln is consistent, but Washington space is hit or miss.  I had bad service, wrong food brought out.....waited for right order and then there were chicken nuckles in my dish- couldn't eat it.  Would love to see quality control take hold on the Washington space because I still believe...

Not bad for a Sunday brunch. I've been here twice now for a Sunday brunch. My boyfriend loves the place so much that we drive from the north side to go here, even though there is a Wishbone much closer on Lincoln. The outdoor patio is great, because it's huge and there is some nice people watching. The food is okay - nothing to write home about. Both times I've had the red eggs, which is decent. My boyfriend loved the crunchy french toast. Once the weather gets cooler this will be off our brunch list, but for now it's nice to enjoy the outdoor patio and walk around the neighborhood after we eat.

Ate there today for the first time for lunch, I had the Blackened Chicken with mashed potatoes and gravy and mac 'n cheese.  Overall a great meal, the chicken was phenomenal and the sides were decent.  I had a Turtle Sundae for dessert and that was great as well.   A great outdoor seating area made this meal even better and helped to make up for the sub-par service.  I wouldn't say the service was terrible, just not at all attentive - I had to ask for an ice tea refill 3 times before it came and we waited quite a bit to finally receive our bill. Overall, a decent place and I will definitely plan on returning.

Went here for lunch during the week, not crowded. Have a somewhat sizable outside patio with your basic lawn chairs. Service was slow and food was so-so. The mac n cheese is not that great. I'll have to check this place out for weekend brunch. Seems to have a lot of seating, but I'm sure there is still a long wait.

After visits to the South, New Orleans, Texas, and Wishbone, I'm fairly certain that in my next life I want to come back as someone from Alabama, Louisiana, or South Carolina.  I'll take all y'all Yankees criticism if I get to eat blackened catfish, cheese grits, and all other fried delights on a daily basis ... This gets a lifetime achievement award from me.  I've been to this place probably a half dozen times, either meeting up for brunch with friends or looking for hangover food.   While I've never really been sold on Wishbone's service, per se, what it lacks in service it makes up for in southern food delights.  I've really enjoyed their blackened catfish and blackened chicken (though they have a tendency to overcook the chicken).   And their grits are damn good too.  Their brunch menu tends to err on the side of seafood (lots of crab, shrimp, and catfish dishes), but that is okay in my book.  Also, be prepared to eat chicken sausage, which completely defeats the purpose of Andouille sausage, but it is a mere price to pay for overall goodness elsewhere.  Unlike other reviewers, I've never had an issue with a lack of salt or a lack of spice in their rice dishes.  I'll agree that the cornbread is a bit dry, though.    One thing to remember about this place is that you'll likely be waiting for a table on the weekend.  And you'll definitely be waiting for a table for at least 30 minutes if you want to sit outside on a nice day.   So, if you like Southern comfort food, this is a darn good place to start.  If you want to avoid a wait, well, this isn't the place for you, you damn Yankee!
Food tasted great, but I had terrible heartburn the rest of the day.  I get heartburn so rarely that I felt it was worth mentioning.  Nice patio to have brunch on, if you like that kind of thing.

I visited Wishbone for the first time last Saturday after hearing rave reviews.  I ordered the Crawfish Cakes and it was definitely a good choice.  They had a bit of spice and tasted great with the Hollandaise sauce.  The service was not very good, but I would definitely go back to try more of the Southern specialties.

A very good breakfast place in Chicago.  I was told whenever I visited the city to come check it out. I'm glad I did.  The andouille sausage hash, the perfectly prepared eggs, heck, even the menu was kickass.  I was worried that my expectations were too high for this place, but it was the definite breakfast/brunch highlight of my recent trip there. As my friend put it, "I wish I could ship this whole restaurant back home ."

Very average food!  If you want better comfort food, check out Lucky Platter in Evanston...far superior.  Even the famous cornbread muffins were dry and boring.  It was very nice sitting outside however and we were seated quickly

Wishbone's food is awesome - it is one of my favorite brunch spots in Chicago.  The restaurant is a block away from my house.  Why two stars?  There service has become horrible in the last few months.  Last week we sat inside and walked out after not being helped for 10 minutes.  There were approximately seven waitstaff and ten tables of people.  I made eye contact with at least half of them, no one wanted to serve us.  The time before that I was rudely told that the restaurant didn't open for another 10 minutes.  Well than why wasn't the door locked? I have much better luck when I order the food as carryout and do not have to deal with the bad service.

One word: YUM. I had Crawfish Cakes with grits, 2 eggs and a corn muffin.  I didn't finish everything, but I wanted to.  My freind had the biscuits and sausage gravy and that smelled wonderful. It was about 11am when we got there and had to valet because parking in the area stinks, but there was no wait at the door.  That's a huge plus in my book. We enjoyed ourselves and I can't wait to go back!!!

This place is GREAT! I love the variety of things to choose from. From corn and black bean cakes to chicken with mango salsa.  Save room for dessert here it's wonderful! You've got to try the cucumber lemonade!! I've never had to wait longer than 10 mins and the service is adequate.  I'm from the south and lots of these items wouldn't make it on any southern menu I've seen.  Nonetheless it's still great food!  Give it a try!

The food is pricey. The decor borders on garish.  The service can be slow. You WILL wait forever, especially on Sundays. The tables are very close to each other. It's a drive for me to get there.  Now:  The food is pricey, yes. And it's cooked just about perfect, IMO. I love how everything tastes non-commercial, like someone actually made this in a proper home kitchen and then thought, you know, hey - I could serve this in a restaurant! I am willing to pay for better quality, and that's what happens here.  The decor is...eclectic. The owners were adamant about that sort of style, and they are characters themselves. Why do I know this? because my best friend designed it to their wishes, a long time ago. I think it's funky. Where else can you go and see that kind of art up on the walls? I like it.  Slow service. Well...yeah. I can't really spin that one, other than the fact that it has been SO FARGING BUSY whenever I've been there, and everything is so...difficult to navigate...that it makes sense. It's not an awful time to wait, but figure maybe 20-30 minutes past the order when it's busy. The Sunday wait is unavoidable, by and large. Church groups, families, groups of sheepishly hung over friends...you will find them all here. You will be sat after them. Happens. But you know, I would rather wait a bit at a restaurant, because really, a line is a good sign when you think about it. The tables are indeed very close. It's annoying when the idiot the next table over continually elbows your shoulder, or won't get up out of his chair when the leg of said chair is on your coat, or talks too loud. Every so often, I have seen good conversation start up between two tables full of people who didn't even know each other. But let's face it: they are trying to pack them in. The line is crazy - there are tons of people. And they could have a mutiny on their hands if it isn't all orchestrated right. So, I look the other way on this minor irritation of the personal space bubble. Yup. It's in the middle of an area that is being built up right now. I live in Logan Square, so this means a drive down I-90 and then sharking for parking. But for that andouille hash...and the fresh-squeezed juices...and the corn muffins, slathered in salted butter...worth it.  Simply worth it.

They have a nice large outdoor seating area.  That only makes it more disappointing that everything else makes this a place I avoid. One note is I have only been to brunch.  I wish I could do an even review having tried everything else, but my few brunch experiences have been so bad I don't want to take the chance. The last time I went just recently so a friend could try the Southern food she thought she was craving the service sucked.  Half ass, slow thinking, indifferent waiter is what I got.    For example on refilling my water once and poured some ice water on to my half finished meal plate where upon his response was a simple oops and walk away. The killer is beyond this the food is bland.  I mean I expect some flavor, some spices, etc for this type of cuisine.  Jambalaya omlette was like eggs with some chicken chunks and a very light dose of tomato sauce.  Bland, bland, bland.  Had to drench it in the hot sauce to get some flavor.  Crab cakes were slightly better but still seemed like a D+ frozen product from Jewel. The corn bread muffins are pretty good.  But how hard can it be to make decent corn bread muffins.  Oh and the Peppar Mary drink I kind of liked, but it isn't any bargain for sure.

Oh wishbone. How I love you. You make me oh so happy... So let me just say that I am originally from New Orleans, born and raised. Let me also say that I hate these places that advertise their "southern style" cuisine. Yuck. Yes I'm a snob because I know what this stuff is SUPPOSED to taste like. Most times it does not. However, Wishbone you have made me a believer!  Usually I go for dinner. I love the blackened salmon with macaroni and cheese. Delicious. Today I tried them for brunch. I had friends in from out of town (New Orleans to be exact  so yes they are food snobs too!). There was a bit of a wait but not as bad as I thought. We were quoted 30 mins but we were sat in about 15 minutes. Brunch was great! I had the crawfish cakes with cheese grits and my friends had the croissants with spinach, egg and cheese and the salmon cakes. Needless to say my friends were impressed and I was a hero for picking an excellent brunch place! Cheers to me. So why only 4 stars? Well that can be attributed to the waitress this morning. One of my friends is a bit of a germaphobe and asked the waitress to please put her water in a to-go cup and not a glass. The waitress looked at her like she had just pulled out her left tit! Then she asked why? BECAUSE SHE F-ING ASKED YOU TO. Of course I did not say this but I sure as hell was thinking it! then after she gave her the water she came back and asked very snootily "how's your water?" There were two other people at the table drinking water. She didn't ask us. So we felt offended by her. It is not her job to judge or make fun of her customers and their little idiosyncrasies. Also I ordered a watermelon lemonade. When she brought it to the table it was frozen. I was unaware of this because it was not stated on the menu. It said fresh squeezed. I explained this to her and she just gave me a blank look. Then she finally asked me if I still wanted it. I told her no. She took the drink and NEVER asked me what I wanted to drink instead. So I just drank water.  So boo for her and her nasty attitude. I'm sure she won't be there for long. Other than that we still had an excellent brunch and yes I was still the hero. :-)

At least once a month for the last year or so I have been to Wishbone. This place never let's me down when it comes to breakfast. My best friend and I discovered this place and it now is one of our favorite places to meet for breakfast.  I visit the one on Washington Blvd. This place gets crowded fast! We usually head to the Starbucks on Morgan & Madison first beforehand.  Wishbone opens @ 8am. We try and make sure we are there at around that time for  the best seats. By 9:30, this place is packed! When the weather is nice outside, we opted to sit outside. It pretty pleasant and lots of good people watching.  One of my favorite dishes there for breakfast is the egg & spinach croissant sandwich.  Simply delicious. Their homefries are excellent too. Overall, I have had great experiences with Wishbone. Getting there early for breakfast is highly reccomended.

I have been a fan of Wishbone for a while.  I would go every Saturday and eat at the counter (the wait can be pretty long if you want a table).  They have the best bacon and potatoes in Chicago.  Lately though the sauteed onions on the potatoes aren't crispy enough , kinda undercooked.  The franch toast is also delicious.  I've never had lunch/dinner. but I heard it's good as well. The service on the other hand is not good.  I've had some awful servers who forget to ever bring our drinks, make you wait forever to order or get/pay the check, not checking back for refills or anything else.  I know they are busy, so I think they should either have more staff on and have a staff more equipped to deal with the volume.  I have even written the manager to complain about a particulary awful server once.  The manager emailed me back to find out more about the problem I had with the waitress and told me he would send me a gift certificate to make up for the experience.  I never received the certificate, but at least he did respond to me and hopefully made an effort to make the servers do a better job hopefully.  Overall they have the best breakfast in Chicago, but be prepared to wait to get a table and not have very attentive servers.

Solid brunch option.  Enjoyed the biscuits/gravy, corn cakes, and crawfish cakes.  Still afraid to try the Southern Benedict without a side of Lipitor.  Missippi mud coffee drink wasn't as thick as advertised.

I wish for some meatloaf from Wishbone!!! They honestly have the best meatloaf with 2 sides. I get the mashed potatoes and mashed sweet potato...what can I say I like my potatoes!!!:-) I had the brunch once and I'm not a fun, but if you want some yummy meatloaf with tomato  sauce and some good sides, this is the place to go!!!

I've been missing out on this popular brunch spot for 2 reasons: 1) it's far from where I live- far meaning requires a cab 2) Southern food doesn't do it for me Today I put aside my fears of Southern style and hopped in a cab to make my way to Wishbone.  I was worried about a long wait based on the other yelp reviews, but they sat us down right away...must be my lucky day!  In an attempt to be healthy, but still not miss out on the good stuff my friend and I split the light spinach egg white omelet and crunchy french toast.  Both were amazing! We added feta cheese to our spinach omelet, which made it extra good.  Our waitress was wonderful and had us satisfied customers in and out within an hour. No more excuses for not going to Wishbone- I'll be back soon and I may even get the grits next time!

Just went there again this Sunday....it was PACKED.   Waited about 25min and decided to sit at the counter since it would've of been another 15min before getting a table...plus we were starved.  Service was average (we never got the biscuit and gravy we ordered), but the food we did get was great.  I had the Crab Cakes which were delicious, and my boyfriend had the Eggs Florentine that he talked about for the rest of the day.   I really like coming here, but prefer to go on a weekday when it's not so busy......

I now consider chef Joel Nickson a friend, but I was enjoying his cooking long before I ever met him. His first Chicago place over on Grand Ave. was THE spot for weekend breakfast (the wait be damned), even before branching out to the West Loop, Lincoln Park and now... FitzGerald's Nightclub in Berwyn. Here's the deal about Wishbone's food, and every other restaurant in the world: Consistency is the holy grail, as everyone has a slightly different interpretation on a recipe, regardless of measurements and training and skill level. That's what's good AND bad about cooking - every individual imparts a slightly different feel into what appears to be the same dish - on paper, anyway.  Not to say Wishbone's food isn't good - it definitely is. But when Joel's cooking, his personality, style & chemistry all come together in the kitchen, it's just dynamite on a plate. As I've told Joel, I think whichever of his restaurants he happens to be working at the time has the best food - because he's there to keep an eye on things.  Another thing about Joel: The guy really has the "touch," and is truly beloved by his customers. The guy has more fans in the city than you can imagine, from heavy politicians to world-famous professional athletes to artists & musicians, famous entertainers (whassup, Oprah!) to mobsters, cops, ad agencies and everyone in between. Quite a blend. Finally, somebody show me another restaurant in town where there seems to be an equal appeal with black &  white customers, all digging the same menu, sitting side by side during a crazy busy brunch. Now THAT'S what's known as a "wide demographic..."

Just ok. The corn muffin was good. I'm going to say, it's not worth the wait. My breakfast (bloody mary, omelet, home fries, corn muffin) was decent. Something about this place kind of grosses me out. There are too many other great options in the city. Sorry Wishbone :(

I was visiting from out of town and my friend Erica told me that this place was just "it" when it came to brunch in the windy city. She knows I am down to try whatever spots she brings to the table, so off we went. Well, I have to say that Wishbone kind of left me wishing for more. While not awful, it wasn't a what I think I'd envisioned. I feel like the food was a little bland and service was slow. Erica even admitted that it our visit wasn't up to par with other times she'd gone.  Guess I'll give a tug at Wishbone again next time I visit. Seems like I got the smaller half on the first pull.

We tried Wishbone this morning (Saturday) as a change from our South Loop Bongo Room/Orange habit.  I was glad that they offered $6 valet, because I was far too hungry to drive around searching for scarce street parking. The restaurant is huge and we were seated immediately, though the place was crowded and larger groups were waiting for tables.  We were approached quickly and both ordered mochas served in pint glasses - pretty tasty and huge. I have the bean cakes and eggs with home fries and a biscuit.  M. henry has my holy grail of bean cakes, to which all others are measured - and these did not stack up, as they were overcooked and dried out.  The mango salsa with them was tasty.  Scrambled eggs are pretty basic, but mine weren't great, they kind of tasted like fake eggs.  The home fries were absolutely delicious, well-seasoned and the perfect texture, and the biscuit was also really tasty. My bf had the crab cakes which were also dry and overcooked, but had potential.  He had cheese grits and a corn muffin - the grits were pretty good, but the corn muffin was dry and bland. Pros - biscuits, home fries, grits, huge mochas, friendly/quick service, valet. Cons - dry bean/crab cakes, bland corn muffins, weird eggs. Wishbone is ok, but not great.  I would give it another shot, but there are so many brunch spots to hit that it might take awhile.

My entire painting class showed up here unannounced on a Thursday morning and were immediately seated and served.  Wishbone has some wonderful staff and lovely decor.  And they serve a nice plate of pancakes for about $4.50.  Great for the art student's budget and a short walk from a number of west loop galleries.
I love Wishbone. The red eggs are my favorite but everything is so tasty there and Wishbone is definitely worth the wait. I like this location the best but I do miss the one that used to be on Grand.

I love Wishbone's. It's one of my new favorite breakfast spots. I had a great omelete- it was the Wishbone's omelete with potatoes and toast. They had very good coffee and my cup was never empty. Our waitress was very friendly and always around if we needed anything. I want to try the cornbread as I've heard its amazing. We didn't have to wait at all for a table on a busy Saturday morning. I'll definitely be going back. Edit: The service I recently received was AWFUL. It took forever to get water/coffee, and our server barely attended our table because she had too many. Our food took a long time as well, and we waited well over 15 minutes for our check. I hope this was just a fluke, as I do like the food!

Love Southern food.  Love brunch.   It's a short wait for a table, even on a busy Sunday morning.  The service can be variable, we've had good and bad.  Most importantly, the food is excellent...except for the salmon cakes.

I have been to Wishbone (both locations) more times than I care to count, but always for brunch. Years of waking up and heading to the west loop for black bean cakes and mango salsa but i never gave athough to what they served AFTER the bloody marys ran dry. But last week I had the pleasure of dining here for dinner and it was FANSTASTIC. I ordered the pan-friend chicken and it was so great. Perfectly crispy skin, meaty and flavorful meat. I make a mean fried chicken myself, and usually find restaurant versions weak and flavorless so this was a pleasant surprise. For my sides and I had the masjed sweet potatoes (prefection) and the black beans. Needless to say I was absolutely stuffed by the time we finished. The waitress was a perfect sweetheart and everyone at my table was pleased with the experience. I can't wait to go back for dinner.

The food at Wishbone is ok, but I am a bit disappointed at their pretty limited menu.  I walk by this place some mornings, and it's packed for brunch, so maybe I should go for brunch and not lunch.  The service has been pretty decent when I've gone, but there's really nothing spectacular about Wishbone.  The corn muffins are really good, but everything else just seems ordinary.  I don't make a special effort to go here, but I don't object if my friends want to go.  I just re-read my review and it's kind of boring.  Well, that about sums it up!

I lived in TN for a little while, and I've always missed grits and gravy. So I might be a bit biased, but it really is a decent place. Friendly staff. Their food could be better, but we are over a thousand miles away from the south. Great bread pudding! Yum!

The mac n cheese is yum,also the bean cake and hoppin john. Was sad that the greens were made with smoked turkey (don't eat it) but I have been told that is the real way to cook them. Service was good as was the price. It is a great place to go for comfort food

brunch is to die for!  i take all of my out-of-town guests here.  try the fruit (mango!) pancakes (with the fruit actually in the batter, not just on top!) or the french toast battered in cornflakes.  sounds weird, but SO GOOD.  the lunch and dinner food isn't my favorite, but then, i've only had it catered.  it may be better in the restaurant.  like most everyone else says, the cornbread is amazing.  be prepared to wait for awhile if you go for brunch at least.

Having grown up in the South, I'm pretty picky about my southern cuisine. This place does a good job of filling my void between jaunts home. Definitely not healthy, but certainly flavorful and tasty. If you want a fruit cup for breakfast, this isn't your place. But if you know how to rock a plate of biscuits with sausage gravy, Wishbone will take care of you.

It's really bizarre that in visiting my mom in Chicago, I had more southern food than I had when I visited her in Indiana. But no complaints from me about that.  I love southern food.  And Wiishbone was very tasty.  Don't go here for grease laden ffood - as they call it - it's southern reconstruction cooking....I'm guessing reconstruction is a play on deconstructed because although they have plenty of southern favorites, nothing looked real heavy like southern food elsewhere (I'm thinking BSmiths and Georgia Brown's in DC).  You'll leave full, but not comatosed. The prices were reasonable and lunch service was quick.  I had the blackened catfish with coleslaw, spinach and mashed sweetpotatoes.  Those potatoes were sooooo good - I was tempted to lick the plate.  They also complimented the very tart and lemony steamed spinach.  The catfish was perfectly seasoned.  Mom was very happy with her Mango Chicken.  We both had flavored lemonades which are served slightly slushed...they are tart and just sweet enough - not syruppy at all.  The corn muffin was a little dry, but that's what butter is for, right?   I also left with a wishbone T-shirt....only $10 and very cute.  Makes a nice statement - says: war is a failure of the imagination - but very subtly. I'll probably be back with my mom and will consider using Wishbone to cater for work events that I have in chicago (depends on location).

I've dined here enough times to say with some authority that only under duress will I come here again. Shrimp and grits is a tasty dish, but the rest of the dinner fare leaves me cold. Bland rice, dull beans, uninspired chicken. Brunch doesn' t make me feel much better. Corn cakes are fine, but too dry for my taste. I like things that don't dry my mouth out. I think the kitchen is shy of using salt...maybe out of sensitivity to their patrons with high blood pressure? Who knows...but a slightly heavier hand will help on all fronts.

"I will eat anything that is chicken fried"  Wishbone reminds me of eating in New Orleans, except there is less pork and more yuppies... neither of which I have a palate for.  None, the less Wishbone is a happen place that gets down with some Southern Comfort food.  Atmosphere:  Its like like a fusion of chic art and  the antique roadshow barfing.  Overall close tables of 2-4 and overall noisy atmosphere makes it a welcoming spot.  Service: Wearing classic Wishbone t-shirts, they are a polite mix of helpful and downright sassy.  Our waitress was polite but dished a little bit of dirt.  Food:  One word...cornbread (Ain't nothing wrong with that!).  Seriously I nearly filled up on their amazing cornbread muffins that come with each meal.  I partook in the Peppercorn New York Strip, which was "so-so", but the side of Macaroni and Cheese and Mashed Potato and Chives made up for that.  Menu is pretty much your "comfort foods" and overall stuff that the little old ladies on your neighborhood would make.  However, good 'ol fried catfish and crabcakes with a hint of Southern vibe make it on the menu.  Mommy Factor:  This is a family friendly place, with enough bustle to keep the folks entertained.  Date Factor:  Not a bad place for a "going out" dinner if your are not intending to wow him/her with an extensive wine collection.  Its not the Four Seasons.  Bling:  Ranging about $10-15 for Dinner, which included a hearty portions and as much cornbread that a slightly overzealous "you might think he had a tapeworm" boy he could eat.

Cheese grits, biscuits and gravy, orange julius, bloody mary... yum! Great place for southern comfort food, and a great place to take visitors once they're sick of the pizza and hot dogs thing. The place can get packed during weekend brunch so if you don't like to wait, time your visit well. Btw - for some reason the Washington location doesn't always have orange julius, but the Lakeview location does.

I really like Wishbone on a couple of different levels.  They care about their customers and their dining experience.  The food is always fresh with high quality ingredients that are environmentally friendly.   Wishbone doesn't serve environmentally friendly and organic foods as a gimmick.  They genuinely care about their customers and the environment.  They could easily promote this or charge a premium, but they don't.  It's still one of the most reasonable places to eat in or out of the city.  I wouldn't try it out for the first time on a Sunday morning.  You don't get a feel of the restaurant because it's so crazy busy. On a side note, I met one of the owners while drinking some coffee.  He is very nice and real.  The conversation wasn't the same blah, blah, blah you get.  Maybe I'm a dork, but I appreciated it.

GREAT FOOD. You aren't going to get in and out of there quick and you are going to be STUFFED...but thats OK with me. The Crab Cakes are FANTASTIC, and the staff is nothing but friendly. I didn't have any Jim Beam there, I don't think they serve it...i dunno.
Great Seafood Gumbo. Nice Waitress. Nice Atmosphere. Above Average hormone-free burger. Tasty black bean cakes and decent mac and cheese. Overall a nice lunchtime experience.
Have A Date Spend the Night??? Take her to this swanky spot for eggs and Mimosa's.....

Nummie, nummie!  (That's what my grandma used to say!)  I came here today (on a Sunday) and waited a whopping 10 minutes to get seated inside, which actually was a great wait (I've heard it's been up to an hour!).  Service was quick, and polite, and overall atmosphere was good.  Food was tasty!  I had the corn cakes, which are a twist on an old favorite.  They added corn meal to the pancake mix, along with scallion and corn.  The end result is rather tasty!  I also had the Apple-Ginger fresh squeezed juice that was also quite tasty! Check it out!

i have only been there for brunch. if you are smart you will get a bloody mary and a biscuit while you wait, which can be oven an hour on the weekends.  the crawfish benedict is my personal favorite.  there are standard brunch options, but if you don't order southern soul food here you are really missing the point.

I've been to Wishbone many times over the years. I hadn't been there in a while and thought it would be a good choice for a casual dinner with my parent's. My dad loves Cajun food... and so do I. The food is always decent. I'm a fan of the blackened catfish with a side of mac n' cheese and sauteed spinach. It's consistent and always good. The rest of my table's food was good... but not great. This place is inexpensive, which is a perk.... The only complaint I have is that the service has gone down hill. We sat for quite a bit without being approached. The waiter was nice but not nearly attentive enough... and we were not asking for much. A highlight was my mom's strawberry lemonade.
